column43:
FIT TO BE TIDE!

It’s not about braggin’
Nor even to boast
It’s about giving their all
From coast to coast

Carrying the tacklers
For a five yard ride
They’ll not give up
Nor be denied

Our defensive backs
They go for the ball
And the line digs in
When we’re against the wall

They’re stepping up
And not giving ground
Never relenting
Till victory is found

It’s about giving the most
And being the best
Giving more effort
Than all the rest

Pouring their all
Into every play
Having real satisfaction
At the end of the day

Ultimate performance
Is our Crimson Pride
And nothing less
Is FIT TO BE TIDE!

Timothy Jarmon
Copyright 2010

column1:
Message from President Bell and Dr. Pope:

Our University of Alabama community is heartbroken by the loss of our student::: Garrett Walker. Our prayers and deepest sympathy are with his family::: friends and loved ones as we mourn his passing.

Tragedies like this weigh on each of us in different ways. As shared earlier this week::: our Counseling Center is available for those affected by this sad news who desire clinical therapeutic services. They are here to help; call 205-348-3863. Student Care and Well-Being is also available at 205-348-2461 for students who have broader needs; and faculty and staff can reach out to the Employee Assistance Program by calling 800-925-5327. Please take care of yourselves during this time::: and don’t neglect seeking support for your mental and emotional health.

It is in times of challenge that the light of the Capstone shines brightest::: times of adversity and heartache where the hope and bond we share find their greatest purpose. We encourage each of you to reach out when you need help and look for ways to inspire those around you. We are all Tide Together.

https://news.ua.edu/2021/11/message-from-the-president-and-vp-for-student-life/

column6: Honoring our Vets. My Dad Ray E Parrish served in the Army as a tànk driver at the battle of the bulge and my brother Lee parrish in the Navy on the USS Ajax off shore of Japan
column7:
Honoring my husband James G Dewitt a US Army Veteran who served in Vietnam as a Huey helicopter pilot::: and in the National Guard for a total of almost 30 years. He is a 1966 graduate of the University of Alabama and was commissioned as a 2nd Lt. upon graduating. While at the University::: he was a member of the Army ROTC honorary society The Scabbard and Blade and served as Executive Officer of the Crimson Guard an Army ROTC drill team. He is an alumni
of Pi Kappa Phi social fraternity at Bama and Phi Kappa Psi::: a business Fraternity. My husband and I are members of the University of Alabama National Alumni Association where he served as an In-state vice-president for 2 years.

column1:
Dear Students:::

We were incredibly saddened this weekend to learn that a member of our UA student community::: Garrett Walker::: is missing. The safety and security of all our students is our priority::: and our UAPD officers have been tirelessly at work in collaboration with the Tuscaloosa Police Department and other community officials to find Garrett. We remain hopeful he will be found in good health very soon. If you have any information that may be helpful in this search::: please call UAPD at 205-348-5454.

I recognize this can be a difficult and uncertain time for our UA community. If you find yourself in need of support::: I encourage you to connect with the University Counseling Center. Call 205-348-3863 to speak with a counselor. Our Student Care and Well-Being office is also here to support you; contact them at 205-348-2461. The staff members in these offices are passionate about helping you::: so do not hesitate to reach out to them.

It is my privilege to serve you. Especially during this time::: you are on my mind and in my heart. Please know that we are here for you and want to support you however we can.

Sincerely:::
Myron L. Pope::: Ed.D.
Vice President for Student Life

column1:
Night falls. A thick::: black::: curtain of darkness envelops the sky.

Suddenly::: a creature with long::: disproportionate claws with flaps of veiny skin between its fingers::: appears in the air flapping its dark-colored skin-wings swiftly. A shimmer of light gleams off the glistening::: prominent::: curved fangs in its agape maw.

Bats - are they dangerous blind blood-suckers or helpful biological pest control? UA's Dr. John Abbott has the inside scoop on these creatures of the night: https://bit.ly/3GGadeG

Tenacious. Dedicated. Unshakeable.

Despite all odds::: Nayeli’s passion and determination earned her a position on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. https://bit.ly/3mdXtEg

Meet Dr. Karla Gower::: the director of the Betsy Plank Center for Public Relations and an endowed faculty member in the PR Department.

Endowed faculty like Dr. Gower are the heart of our campus::: enrich students' education and continue to reinforce UA's standing as a leader in higher education. Through The Rising Tide::: we will bring 75 new faculty endowments to campus. 👏 Dr. Gower's story: https://bit.ly/UARisingTideDrGower #UARisingTide
"Homecoming::: Alabama-style - there's just nothing like it." #RollTide

UA journalism student Ceara Burden secured a prestigious internship with Carnegie-Knight News21 last summer - and she used it as an opportunity to provide a voice to those struggling during the pandemic who weren't in the headlines. How this investigative reporter found inspiration and helped uncover the stories of people with disabilities left behind during COVID-19: https://bit.ly/CearaBurden

21 universities. 10 racecars. 200 mph. 0 drivers.

The Indy Autonomous Challenge = the fastest autonomous racing in the world. 🏁 UA is one of 21 universities from nine countries formed into nine teams to take part in the world's first self-driving racecar competition. Autonomous driving for passenger vehicles is in the future - and the primary goal of the contest is to advance technology that can speed the commercialization of fully autonomous vehicles and deployments of advanced driver-assistance systems. https://bit.ly/IndyAutonomousChallenge

The race for a million dollar prize is happening this Saturday at noon CT. Tune in here to watch: https://www.indyautonomouschallenge.com/

#WhereLegendsAreMade

A UA Fire Alarm Technician::: Hill has been in the fire prevention field of UA's Department of Environmental Health and Safety for more than a decade. In April 2019::: a fire devastated the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris::: France. A little more than two years later::: #TideResearch is contributing to the historic building's restoration.

#UA's Dr. Jennifer M. Feltman::: assistant professor of art history::: is one of 14 specialists appointed to a team of scientists and art historians who have been provided special access to the cathedral to begin their work. She recently traveled to Paris to begin her hands-on research: https://bit.ly/UANotreDameRestoration

column1: What do you wear on Game Days? 🅰️ Through the 1920s::: football games called for suits::: ascots::: bowties::: long skirts::: dresses and furs. Now::: enormous hats have been replaced by headbands::: and leather is much more common than fur. We explore a century of Game Day fashion: https://bit.ly/CenturyOfGameDayFashion 🏈 #RollTide

ng to our seats was exciting because we had a fence between us and Bear Bryant very briefly. The good ole days! RTR forever!!!

“Our champion student-athletes in adapted athletics now have a championship-caliber facility in which to train and compete."

#TodayAtUA::: we held a ribbon-cutting to celebrate the official opening of the Parker-Haun Tennis Facility::: the only collegiate tennis facility in the nation for adapted student-athletes. This new 3:::835-square-foot tennis facility is located immediately adjacent to the student recreation courts managed by University Recreation. The space includes locker rooms::: restrooms::: a trainer’s room and offices for the coaching staff. More on this incredible new facility: https://bit.ly/Parker-HaunTennisFacility

column1: Since 1960::: Tutwiler Hall has been a home away from home to more than 40:::000 UA students. The new Tutwiler is set to be completed August 2022 - and UA students and alumni have a chance to bring home a piece of the original building and support future residents! 💯 How you can own a keepsake from the historic building or leave your legacy on the new space: https://bit.ly/HistoricTutwiler #RollTide
column3: Rm 1035 Tutwiler in 1973::: my freshman year. But::: I thought Tutwiler was pretty new::: then.

The Alabama Department of Public Health's KICK COVID program is offering vaccines on campus during our Sept. 25 game vs. Southern Miss. Students::: faculty/staff and fans who get vaccinated will receive a $75 Supe Store gift card!

There are two ways to participate:
-Get vaccinated between now and Oct. 2 and upload proof of vaccination to kickcovid19.com and receive a $75 campus bookstore gift card

-Get vaccinated on Sept. 25 at the KICK COVID tent near the Walk of Champions from 3:30pm until one hour after the game and receive a $75 Supe Store gift card Visit kickcovid19.com for more information!

*Kick COVID is an incentive program run by the Alabama Department of Public Health.

DYK: About 70% of drugs approved by the FDA were first identified in nature - but the method of teasing out possible chemical compounds from the abundance of plants is time consuming. 🤔 UA's Dr. Lukasz Ciesla is working on improving this process by leading a cutting-edge project with an industrial partner to develop a kit that speeds discovery of potential drug therapies from plants. 🌱 https://bit.ly/DrCieslaNaturalSources #TideResearch

As a first-generation college student of immigrant parents::: Cory D'Az is motivated to make the most of his experience at the Capstone. He is driven to succeed for his parents::: who fled El Salvador's civil war in the 1980s.

Endowed scholarships reinforce UA’s promise to our students. The Rising Tide Capital Campaign will help the next generation of leaders::: such as Cory::: overcome financial obstacles to take advantage of the opportunities offered at the Capstone. His story: https://risingtide.ua.edu/cory-daz/ #UARisingTide

“Hewson Hall is representative of the transformative educational opportunities available at UA and predicated in part on providing the students room and resources they need to collaborate and learn."

In case you missed it: A week ago::: we celebrated the official opening of Hewson Hall with a ribbon-cutting ceremony ✂️ How this building will further enhance the standard of excellence within the Culverhouse College of Business - and the University: https://bit.ly/HewsonHallRibbonCutting #WhereLegendsAreMade

Countless group projects take place every semester at UA - but it's not everyday that those projects turn into an award-winning entrepreneurial venture.

Enter Student Seats. UA grad students John Ritondo and Jared Waller::: decided to take their project to the next level and created a safe ticket exchange for UA students to buy and sell tickets without fear of being scammed. 👏 Student Seats launched in fall 2020 and gained 500 users in its first three days. 😮 It now has 800 users and has gained attention outside of the student body::: winning first place at the 2020 River Pitch Competition and first place in the established business concepts group of the 2021 Edward K. Aldag Jr. Student Business Plan Competition. 💯 https://bit.ly/StudentSeats #RollTide

“…The biggest thing I wished everybody would take away from it is the unity and patriotism. It was a targeted attack against our country. And it did not discriminate::: it took anybody and everybody out. But we are stronger together::: just like our community.”

Twenty years ago::: the world we knew significantly changed within just a few hours::: reshaping almost every aspect of everyday life. For Brad Campbell::: a retired Master Sergeant for the U.S. Air Force::: Sept. 11::: 2001::: will forever be remembered. THE TIDE KEEPS RISING!

With Vols to vanquish
And Tigers to tame
The good times are here
At the top of our game

With bowls to win
And records to bust
our backs a runnin'
and a line to thrust

Every man giving
Only his best
There isn’t any better
In East or West

With Hogs to hunt
And Rebels to rout
Roll Tide Roll
Is what we shout

With Wildcats to whip
And Hurricanes to hammer
Each game ends
With Rammer Jammer

With the Irish erased
And the Bulldogs beat
Our National Titles
Are oh so sweet

With Saban in charge
It’s not surprising
Our time has come
And the Tide Keeps Rising!

Timothy C. Jarmon
Copyright 2017

column1: Students spent their morning volunteering around our local community as part of Ripple Effect - which means it's almost time for #FirstDayUA! 💯 This annual day of service gives students a hands-on experience in making a difference in the Tuscaloosa community. 👏 Thank you to these students for being the change and supporting our city! Spotted talking to students at several locations: President Bell and Dr. Pope.

“I have been meeting with local K-12 teachers to engage the needs of their students and coordinate literacy workshops that focus on poetry::: creative storytelling and writing college applications. I have also been designing visual grant proposals to fundraise money to complete renovations and interior design plans.”

Summer can be the perfect time to grow::: learn and help others - and many students::: faculty and staff did just that over the last few months! How some members of the UA community spent their summer break: https://bit.ly/UASummerBreakStories

We've been busy welcoming students to campus this week - Move-In is officially here and the beginning of the fall semester is just days away!! 🅰️ Spotted during Move-In: President Bell and Dr. Pope.

column1: A new academic year is about to begin::: and we're excited to welcome new students to the Capstone! 💯 SGA President Jillian Fields has a guide just for you on all things UA ↓ #RollTide

Students are moving back to Tuscaloosa and campus is getting busy - and #FirstDayUA is only a week away!! 😳 If you're part of our alumni family::: drop some tips below to help incoming students have a successful first day of class next week! 💯 #RollTide

Our pro-tip: Find a campus map with photos of buildings on the UA Safety app! 📱
column5: Yes::: the answer to most questions is "IT IS IN THE SYLLABUS". Also::: limit your partying to the weekends. Tuscaloosa and the university offer fun things to do every day of the week. column20:
Don’t try to schedule all of your classes on Tuesdays and Thursdays. 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. only two days a week doesn’t sound so bad until you’re 5 hours deep in that day. It makes for long days with very few breaks.

Also::: it’s ok if you don’t go home much the first semester because you will be really busy. The second semester will come around and you’ll be missing home so much that you will probably visit often.

Finally::: make friends in your classes::: preferably with the kid who asks a lot of questions or the smartest kid in class—you’ll learn a lot from them. Don’t be a bum though—pull your weight and don’t let your group members down on projects.

Update to UA mask policy ↓

The University of Alabama will require face coverings indoors on campus::: where and when distancing is not possible::: beginning Friday::: Aug. 6. This requirement applies to everyone::: regardless of vaccination status. Given the increase in COVID cases and recent CDC guidance::: UA is taking this step to further protect the Fall 2021 Semester.

With this new requirement::: masks must be worn:
-In classrooms and classroom buildings::: regardless of distancing
-In personal meeting spaces::: such as meetings with faculty and advisors
-When gathering in common spaces::: such as the Student Center
-On campus transportation

Exceptions include:
-Indoor areas when distanced
-When alone in offices and private workspaces
-In residence hall rooms
-While eating or drinking
-While exercising
-Faculty teaching::: if distanced and behind plexiglass

The indoor masking requirement is intended to be temporary and will be reviewed after the first two weeks of classes. Guidance and data are continually reviewed by medical professionals and administrators working with the campus Situational Response Team and the UA System Health and Safety Task Force.

“Vaccinations are the key to a successful fall semester and the key to moving beyond these types of requirements:::” stated Dr. Ricky Friend::: dean of the College of Community Health Sciences. “Everyone is strongly encouraged to be vaccinated. Data continue to show the vaccines provide very strong protection against serious illness and hospitalization.”

Schedule your vaccination appointment today::: or let us know if you’ve been vaccinated. Students who upload proof of vaccination will qualify for $20 Bama Cash.

“Our vaccine numbers among faculty and staff are strong — the percentage vaccinated more than doubles the statewide number. We are still learning about students who were vaccinated over the summer::: and will be offering expanded opportunities for vaccination as classes approach. Again::: vaccination is key:::” Friend said.

Check the UA HealthInfo website for the latest information.

column28:
Carbon dioxide re-breathing with close fitting face respirator masks

S. J. Fletcher
Guidelines for the use of personal protective equipment when caring for patients who are affected by highly infectious pathogens such as SARS::: avian influenza and tuberculosis include the use of high efficiency respirators that filter at least 95% of particles with a median diameter of 0.1 micron. These must therefore be close fitting to prevent air leakage [1::: 2]. A healthy intensivist (SF)::: wearing such a respirator (Tecnol Fluidshield PFR95::: Kimberly Clark Corporation::: Roswell::: GA) to perform a percutaneous tracheostomy on a patient with multidrug resistant pulmonary tuberculosis::: experienced dyspnoea::: tachycardia and tremor after 30 min. End-tidal carbon dioxide measured at the mouth by hand-held capnometry was 6.3 kPa (normal value 5.3 kPa). We postulated that the symptoms were due to hypercapnia.

We measured the end-tidal carbon dioxide levels in four anaesthetists wearing the same design of mask::: before and after performing tracheal intubation on another patient with pulmonary tuberculosis. Measurements were taken by sidestream capnometer (Poet LT::: Criticare::: Waukesha::: WI) using a 15-mm T-piece held between the lips. The mean baseline end-tidal carbon dioxide level was 5.18 kPa. Post-procedure (20 min later) the mean end-tidal carbon dioxide level was 5.95 kPa (p = 0.007). No subjects reported symptoms of hypercapnia. The rise in end-tidal carbon dioxide is due to rebreathing of expired alveolar gas that is ‘trapped’ in the respirator::: with the degree of rebreathing being proportional to the volume of the respirator (‘dead space’). It is likely that all tight-fitting::: high efficiency respirators will behave similarly::: with only the size of dead space varying between designs.

The respiratory response to hypercapnia is an increase in minute ventilation::: giving rise to the sensation of dyspnoea. Moderate (6.18 kPa) to high (7.5 kPa) levels of end-tidal carbon dioxide have also been shown to impair significantly cognitive and psychomotor performance and it is likely that this effect of carbon dioxide is dose related with no threshold []. Clearly::: our findings are of uncertain practical significance and further trials would be required employing cognitive and psychomotor measurements and arterial blood gas analysis.

In the event of an influenza pandemic::: large numbers of healthcare workers may need to wear these respirators for prolonged periods and problems with hypercapnia might reduce the tolerability of these devices. Whether psychomotor performance is affected also remains to be seen.

47 studies confirming that masks are useless in preventing Covid infection and transmission This has been a growing::: serious concern in recent months as the dangerous health and emotional effects::: especially on children::: who are at almost zero risk of Covid harm::: are becoming more pronounced and deeply worrisome.

VARIOUS FACE MASK STUDIES PROVE THEIR INEFFECTIVENESS
1. Surgical mask / cloth face mask studies
Community and Close Contact Exposures Associated with COVID-19 Among Symptomatic Adults ≥18 Years in 11 Outpatient Health Care Facilities — United States::: July 2020

The US Centre for Disease Control performed a study which showed that 85 percent of those who contracted Covid-19 during July 2020 were mask wearers. Just 3.9 percent of the study participants never wore a mask.
Original: https://
www.cdc.gov/
mmwr/volumes/69/
wr/pdfs/
mm6936a5-H.pdf
Erratum. correction: https://
www.cdc.gov/
mmwr/volumes/69/
wr/
mm6938a7.htm?s_c
id=mm6938a7_w https://
www.theblaze.com
/op-ed/
horowitz-cdc-stu
dy-covid-masks

2. Facial protection for healthcare workers during pandemics: a scoping review
This study used 5462 peer-reviewed articles and 41 grey literature records.

“Conclusion: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to critical shortages of medical-grade PPE. Alternative forms of facial protection offer inferior protection. More robust evidence is required on different types of medical-grade facial protection. As research on COVID-19 advances::: investigators should continue to examine the impact on alternatives of medical-grade facial protection”
So how is your cloth and surgical mask working again if EVEN medical grade alternatives are failing ?
Study Article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
32371574/

3. Physical interventions to interrupt or reduce the spread of respiratory viruses
“There is moderate certainty evidence that wearing a mask probably makes little or no difference to the outcome of laboratory-conf
irmed influenza compared to not wearing a mask”

Study article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
33215698/

4. Disposable surgical face masks for preventing surgical wound infection in clean surgery
“We included three trials::: involving a total of 2106 participants. There was no statistically significant difference in infection rates between the masked and unmasked group in any of the trials”

Study article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
27115326/

5. Disposable surgical face masks: a systematic review
Two randomized controlled trials were included involving a total of 1453 patients. In a small trial there was a trend towards masks being associated with fewer infections::: whereas in a large trial there was no difference in infection rates between the masked and unmasked group.

Study article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
16295987/

6. Evaluating the efficacy of cloth facemasks in reducing particulate matter exposure
“Our results suggest that cloth masks are only marginally beneficial in protecting individuals from particles<2.5 μm”

Study article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
27531371/

7. Face seal leakage of half masks and surgical masks
“The filtration efficiency of the filter materials was good::: over 95%::: for particles above 5 micron in diameter but great variation existed for smaller particles.

Coronavirus is 0.125 microns. therefore these masks wouldn’t protect you from the virus”

Study article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
4014006/

8. Comparison of the Filter Efficiency of Medical Nonwoven Fabrics against Three Different Microbe Aerosols
“The filter efficiencies against influenza virus particles were the lowest”

“We conclude that the filter efficiency test using the phi-X174 phage aerosol may overestimate the protective performance of nonwoven fabrics with filter structure compared to that against real pathogens such as the influenza virus”
Study article: https://
pubmed.ncbi.nlm.
nih.gov/
29910210/

9. Aerosol penetration through surgical masks

column126:
I never dreamed that I would have to face the prospect of not living in the United States of America::: at least not the one I have known all my life. I have never wished to live anywhere else. This is my home and I was privileged to be born here.
But today I woke up and as I had my morning coffee I realized that everything is about to change. No matter how I vote::: no matter what I say::: something evil has invaded our nation::: and our lives are never going to be the same. I have been confused by the hostility of family and friends. I look at people I have known all my life so filled with hate that they will agree with opinions that if they were in their right minds they would never express as their own. It's absolutely unbelievable. I think that I may well have entered the Twilight Zone.....then I saw this and I think that it's pretty close to describing how I feel.
I'm not starting a fight::: but it is something to think about. This may open up a ton of outraged comments by some. Many who will argue how "wrong" this post is. My suggestion::: save your time and effort! You're not changing the reality of what we are living by trying to somehow justify this insanity. Nevertheless::: I couldn't resist because we are becoming the Twilight Zone. We have become a nation that has lost its collective mind!

• Somehow it’s un-American for the census to count how many Americans are in America.

• Russians influencing our elections are bad::: but illegals voting in our elections are good.

• It was cool for Joe Biden to "blackmail" the President of Ukraine::: but it’s an impeachable offense if Donald Trump inquires about it.

• Twenty is too young to drink a beer::: but eighteen is old enough to vote.

• People who have never owned slaves should pay slavery reparations to people who have never been slaves.

• Inflammatory rhetoric is outrageous::: but harassing people in restaurants is virtuous.

• People who have never been to college should pay the debts of college students who took out huge loans for their degrees.

• Immigrants with tuberculosis::: Covid and polio are welcome::: but you’d better be able to prove you're vaccinated to work to pay for them.

• Irish doctors and German engineers who want to immigrate must go through a rigorous vetting process::: but any illiterate gang-bangers who jump the southern fence are welcome.

• $5 billion for border security is too expensive::: but $1.5 trillion for “free” health care is not.

• If you cheat to get into college you go to prison::: but if you cheat to get into the country you go to college for free.

• People who say there is no such thing as gender are demanding a female President.

• We see other countries going Socialist and collapsing::: but it seems like a great plan to us.

• Some people are held responsible for things that happened before they were born::: and other people are not held responsible for what they are doing right now.

• Criminals are catch-and-relea
sed to hurt more people::: but stopping them is bad because it's a violation of THEIR rights.

• And pointing out all this hypocrisy somehow makes us "racists"?!

Nothing makes sense anymore::: no values::: no morals::: no civility and people are dying of a Chinese virus::: but it racist to refer to it as Chinese even though it began in China. We are clearly living in an upside down world where right is wrong and wrong is right::: where moral is immoral and immoral is moral::: where good is evil and evil is good::: where killing murderers is wrong::: but killing innocent babies is right::: where darkness is light and light is now darkness.

Wake up America::: the great unsinkable ship Titanic America has hit an iceberg::: is taking on water and sinking fast. The choice is yours to make. What will it be? Time is short::: make your choice wisely!

Reposting from a friend because I believe it is true although very sad.

column1: It's almost time for round two - we're celebrating more graduates at noon! Congrats to our summer grads from the College of Arts & Sciences::: the College of Community Health Sciences::: the College of Engineering::: the College of Human Environmental Sciences and the School of Social Work. 👏 We hope your years at the Capstone will empower you to go above and beyond in your future endeavors! #BamaGrad 🎓

We’re kicking off today's ceremonies with graduates from the Capstone College of Nursing::: the College of Communication & Information Sciences::: the College of Education and the Culverhouse College of Business. 🎉 Congrats to each and every #BamaGrad - we're so proud of you and can't wait to see how you go out and impact the world! #RollTide 🎓

The big day is almost here - and we know you're ready for that special moment when your grad's name is called and they finally cross that stage! Not able to be here in Tuscaloosa? Don't worry::: we're bringing the ceremonies to you! Check back here tomorrow to see livestreams of the ceremonies happening at 8:30 a.m. and noon. 👍 You can also view livestreams on our YouTube channel: http://bit.ly/UAonYouTube

column1:
Did you know: Fossilized shark teeth can be found in Alabama's Black Belt - and UA's Museum of Natural History shark hunters are leading the state’s only day-long::: public::: fossil excursions this summer! 🦈

The most common species of extinct shark teeth found on the expeditions are from goblin::: crow and mackerel sharks. Hunters could also find American Indian arrowheads::: fossils from ice age mammals::: like broken mammoth tusks::: and every now and again something truly fantastic — a mosasaurus or plesiosaurus tooth.
https://bit.ly/UAFossilExcursions

The national award earned by this hard work: https://bit.ly/UASafeStateAward #RollTide

Our championship roots run deep - and our everyday champions embody the UA spirit of pride::: determination and ingenuity. 🅰️

As the director of University Dining Services::: Kristina Patridge has seen campus evolve from 18:::000 students and six dining locations to now more than 37:::000 students and 32 dining facilities. When the pandemic hit::: Patridge worked tirelessly to make sure dining needs were met across campus - and met safely. From helping students celebrate birthdays while in isolation to preparing game day foods and passing out shakers::: she has been essential in caring for the well-being of UA students during the pandemic. https://bit.ly/EverydayChampionsPatridge

There is no cure for metastatic breast cancer - but #TideResearch is searching for innovative solutions. Dr. Shreyas Rao's lab is working to shed light on drug resistance::: examining how these cancer cells evade drug therapies by using a Jell-O-like model. How and why they're using engineering techniques in the lab: https://bit.ly/3A6OY2i

“We have done art concepts and installations::: but nothing like this or to this scale."

#UA's Jason Guynes::: chair of the department of art and art history::: brought his 20 years of experience in mural painting to create a one-of-a-kind masterpiece showcasing a beloved local landmark - Denny Chimes. Using the ancient technique of sgraffito::: he and his team spent hours chiseling a houndstooth pattern::: the chimes and clouds into plaster on the wall of a local hotel lobby. More about this technique and detailed photos of this work: http://bit.ly/SgraffitoMuralChimes

The University of Alabama is honored to recognize the first official Juneteenth holiday - the day that marks an effective end to slavery in the United States! Juneteenth is the day when federal troops arrived in Galveston::: Texas::: in 1865 to take control of the state and ensure that all enslaved people be freed::: and is considered the longest-running African American holiday. Information on local celebrations: https://bit.ly/3gDGMPq

column7: It is an overreach to say that this limited exposure event in Galveston effectively ended slavery in the United States. The 13th Amendment was not yet ratified - that would take effect later in the year on December 6th and the Emancipation Proclamation did not address slavery in states that had not seceded.

Alabama Softball went on a wild ride this season::: and Montana Fouts was one of the players who helped make it happen. 💯

Leading the nation with 349 strikeouts::: she threw double-digit strikeouts in 22 games - including 14 in a perfect game against UCLA at the Women's College World Series (the fifth in World Series history and first since 2000!) 💪She was named the SEC Co-Pitcher of the Year and SEC Tournament MVP::: leading the Crimson Tide to its sixth tournament title. Congrats to Montana for her most recent accolade::: the 2021 Schutt Sports/NFCA Division-l Pitcher of the Year!! 🥎 http://bit.ly/FoutsPitcherOfTheYear #WhereLegendsAreMade

It's important to make sure you're prepared - you never know when an emergency might happen! Do you know the safest place in the campus building where you work or learn? The Office of Emergency Management is here to help with Building Emergency Plans in each building on campus. These plans are more than just maps - they also contain information that could save your life! Look for them near exits and elevators.

More on campus emergency preparedness: http://bit.ly/BuildingEmergencyPlans

Gilman International scholars receive up to $5:::000 to apply toward their study abroad program costs::: empowering them to gain skills critical to our national security and economic competitiveness. Congrats to our most recent honorees::: Sophia Grillo::: Alana Thompson::: Brooke Wolfe and Daniel Flores Zelaya! http://bit.ly/GilmanInternationalScholars #RollTide

If you live in a coastal region::: you know that storm prep is more than just preparing for fast winds. Sometimes flooding from tropical storms and hurricanes can be overlooked when compared to the wind strength of a tropical cyclone - but flooding is a big problem for coastal communities! #TideResearch is on it::: working to develop advanced computational earth science and coastal models to help these communities prepare for the compounding hazards of coastal flooding::: wind and intense precipitation.
http://bit.ly/TideResearchFloodResiliency

"An MRI scanner on campus is essential for the successful execution of several funded research projects and will allow faculty the capability to pursue future projects.”

Recognized as a top-tier research institution::: we have a growing concentration of neuroimaging and neuroscience researchers. A new addition to the Student Health Center will increase clinical services provided to students AND boost our research capabilities thanks to a new MRI suite: http://bit.ly/SHCAddition #TideResearch

column1:
"We are focused on how we can pave the way for more technology sensitive to ASL::: and thus::: more accessible to the deaf community.”

Smart devices activated with voice commands can be challenging to access by those who use American Sign Language as their primary language - so #TideResearch is pioneering the development of radar-based sign language recognition. The patent-pending technology leverages radio frequency sensing to enable a human-computer interface built from the start to recognize sign language. How it works: http://bit.ly/TideResearchSigningIn

The National Name Exchange is a coalition of top colleges and universities who offer fellowships::: research opportunities and application fee waivers to diverse::: high-achieving graduate prospects. To protect candidates’ privacy::: official invitations will be sent to their Crimson email.

For more info::: follow University of Alabama - Graduate School

We were trying to help feed children during the pandemic::: and that was all the motivation we needed to work as hard as we could to pull together as a team and as a class.”

Students in C&IS instructor Susan Daria’s class didn't let the pandemic stop them from the semester's challenge of raising funds and awareness for local childhood food insecurity. Since 2011::: this class has raised more than $213:::000 for Secret Meals For Hungry Children. How they unleashed their creativity with virtual campaigns that raised money to feed mouths in need + other ways C&IS rose to meet the challenges faced during the pandemic: https://bit.ly/3yfoYkh

Do you know the origin of 92.5 FM UA Info Radio? The National Survey for Student Engagement is open to all first-year students and seniors - and the deadline to take this survey is Saturday::: May 15! Heads up: For added security and convenience::: physical swipe ACT Cards are phasing out this summer and mobile ACT Cards will become the official credential for the UA campus. Starting June 1::: students’ swipe Action Cards::: which feature Denny Chimes on a red background::: will no longer function at readers on and off campus. Faculty and staff swipe Action Cards featuring Denny Chimes will be deactivated on July 13.

Details on how to go mobile: http://bit.ly/SwipeACTCards 📱

"Students and alumni will be able to enjoy the benefits of these trees for many years to come.”

Our sustainability efforts continue::: as we look to begin the initial steps to create a campus tree farm! 🌳 The idea for the project was developed in the summer of 2020 when it was noticed that magnolia seeds were falling from one of the grand specimen trees on the Bryce Campus. Seeds were then collected from other prominent large magnolias from locations across campus such as the President’s Mansion::: Bryce Lawn and Gorgas House. What this means for our campus community: http://bit.ly/TreeFarmLaunch

Boren Scholarships are awarded for the study of languages in world regions critical to U.S. interests and underrepresented in study abroad - and UA student Ann Williams is our most recent honoree! With plans to use her scholarship to study Mandarin in Taiwan::: her immediate goal after school is to be a public diplomacy officer in the foreign service.

A junior majoring in international studies with minors in Chinese and women’s studies::: she also is part of the Blount Scholars Program. She is simultaneously pursuing a master’s degree in public administration through UA’s Accelerated Master’s Program. More on how she plans to use her education from UA to positively impact our world: http://bit.ly/BorenScholar2021 #WhereLegendsAreMade

column1: Over the past academic year::: our community embodied the character of our University. Our resourceful UA staff bolstered our accomplishments::: and our determined UA students boldly pursued their goals::: inspired by a visionary view of the future. Tide Together::: we achieved our highest potential and realized legendary results. #WhereLegendsAreMade

column1: Our last live stream of the commencement weekend celebration is to celebrate graduates of the Culverhouse College of Business with last names that begin with letters P-Z. Grads::: we can't wait to see how you go out and change the world! #BamaGrad 🎓

With our second ceremony of the day::: we're recognizing graduates of the Culverhouse College of Business with last names that begin with letters H-O. A big Roll Tide and congratulations to these grads - we're so proud of you! #BamaGrad

Today we'll be honoring our graduates of the Culverhouse College of Business! Our first ceremony of the day celebrates graduates with last names that begin with letters A-G. Congrats::: grads - your future is bright! 😎 #BamaGrad

We're wrapping up the day celebrating graduates of the College of Human Environmental Sciences and the College of Community Health Sciences. Best of luck to these students as they take their UA education and influence positive change in our world. 👏 #BamaGrad

Roll Tide and congratulations to the graduates of the College of Education and College of Nursing! We hope your years at the Capstone will empower you to go above and beyond in your future endeavors! #BamaGrad
The celebration continues with our second group of graduates from the College of Arts and Sciences::: with students with last names that begin with letters L-Z. Congrats::: graduates! #BamaGrad 🅰️

We're celebrating with round one of our College of Arts and Sciences grads this morning::: with students with last names that begin with letters A-K! Future legends::: we know you'll make us proud. #BamaGrad 🎓
We know these engineering grads are going to go out and do big things! 🅰️ Congrats::: grads - we can't wait to see where your UA education takes you! #BamaGrad

We're kicking off spring 2021 commencement ceremonies with the graduates of the College of Communications and Information Sciences and the School of Social Work. 💯 Congrats to each and every #BamaGrad! 🎓

column1: When Carlisle Washburne crosses the stage this weekend in Coleman Coliseum::: she will be continuing a legacy that started in 1834 - she is the great::: great::: great::: great-granddaughter of one of the first students to graduate from UA. An Honors College student majoring in biology with a double minor in psychology and global and cultural perspectives::: she coincidentally followed a similar path as her ancestor through her own coursework. More on her UA experience and how following in her great::: great::: great::: great grandfather's footsteps has prepared and empowered her for her graduate studies: http://bit.ly/GradCarlisleWashburne

column1: Class of 2021::: your journey ends the same way it began - as champions. As you walk across the commencement stage::: take a moment to reflect on the challenges you've accomplished and the memories you've made. Memories that will accompany you::: influence your future and empower you to become the next legends of The University of Alabama. #BamaGrad 🎓

We can't believe the semester is almost over - commencement begins the day after tomorrow!! 🎓Make your grad cap stand out by using one of our stencils and show everyone how proud you are to be graduating from the place #WhereLegendsAreMade!

Find the stencils here: http://bit.ly/BamaGradCapStencils
#BamaGrad

Today::: we remember.
#TTownNeverDown

There are markers through history that formed The University of Alabama into a new shape::: and April 27::: 2011::: will long be remembered as a devastating day that led to inspiring changes.

Although we will never forget that tragic day::: the strength and resiliency of our community is the lasting legacy that keeps us forever Tide Together.

“The UA community will never forget those we lost and those who suffered that tragic day 10 years ago. As we reflect over the past decade::: we also remember the resiliency of our people in recovering and rebuilding stronger. That day still drives us to improve emergency preparedness::: service to others and our own understanding.” - President Bell

Tomorrow::: April 27::: marks 10 years since the devastating tornado that tore a path through Tuscaloosa just missing campus. The UA and Tuscaloosa communities have bonded together to recover::: rebuild and grow. In the decade since the natural disaster::: UA has girded its storm preparedness to become a leader in the state::: opened avenues for research::: and built deeper::: more sustainable opportunities for students to serve the community. https://bit.ly/32PaRnf
column8: That was my freshman year. I will never forget or let anyone near me forget. The sense of community that followed was more outstanding than any other experience. T-Town Strong
column9: I was there on the Paul Bryant bridge as I watched the tornado as it worked it's terror at the Stadium and then moved quickly in my direction. HA! The killer storm thought it might roll over the tide that day. Didn't happen. We were bruised but not beaten.

column1:
“We need people who are passionate and invested in our communities and making positive changes in health care. We are making progress::: slowly but surely.”

LaDarryl Banks is graduating this spring from UA’s Capstone College of Nursing RN Mobility (RN to BSN) program. Committed to making a difference::: he is an RN and office manager at Cahaba Medical Center’s West End location::: a nonprofit Federally Qualified Health Care Center in Birmingham. He not only provides care to historically underserved populations but also works to improve their community::: which he::: too::: calls home. http://bit.ly/GradLaDarrylBanks #BamaGrad

Military service members and their families make sacrifices every day - and their educational goals should not be one of them. Inspired by the military service members they work with::: the College of Continuing Studies is seeking funding through Bama Blitz to endow a new scholarship for active duty and veteran military service members and their dependents. https://bit.ly/2PWPpdn

“To know that your donation led to the ability for our students to graduate from our program is truly worth its weight in gold.”

The Capstone College of Nursing Student Balance Relief Fund was created to ensure financial constraints don't delay or prevent future health care heroes from earning their degrees. CCN is a national innovator in clinical simulation in nursing education::: utilizing simulators and telehealth technology in teaching::: research and health care delivery - and this passion project gives students the opportunity to finish their degree while utilizing resources that can set them up to be leaders in the world of health care. https://bit.ly/3e8tNCW

“When those who support this Bama Blitz project watch the parade on television this Thanksgiving::: they will know that their support helped make this extraordinary experience possible for our students. All Bama fans will be excited to hear ‘Yea Alabama’ on the streets of Manhattan.”

The Million Dollar Band was selected to appear in the 2020 Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade::: but their invitation was deferred to the 2021 parade when last year’s event was restricted due to the pandemic::: and bands did not participate. This year's Bama Blitz passion project will get them to the 2021 parade - and you can help make it happen!
https://bit.ly/2PS6Agc #BamaBlitz

"The tradition of the class ring is like none other on campus. Receiving your class ring is a coveted rite of passage for UA students::: dating back for many generations. Such a grand tradition surrounds this tiny little ring::: and it is certainly one of the most distinctive of all our Alabama family things."

Congratulations to the students who were presented their class rings at one of today's ceremonies! Learn more about this tradition we hold dear ↓ #RollTide

On Monday::: the class ring tradition continued when the UA Army ROTC placed a large mahogany box filled with class rings inside Denny Chimes. The rings remained there overnight until 6:31 p.m. on Tuesday. The time is significant because it translates to 18:31 in military time::: as 1831 is the year of The University’s founding.

Happening today: These class rings::: now "infused with UA spirit" will be presented to students in three different ceremonies in order to comply with COVID-19 safety precautions::: such as social distancing.

column1: The annual ring ceremony is happening next week! 🅰️ This two-part tradition begins at Denny Chimes::: where UA students and alumni who order official class rings and choose to participate in the ceremony will first have their rings placed in the 115-foot tall::: 92-year-old bell tower for 24 hours. After the rings are "infused with UA spirit:::" they will be transported to the Bryant Conference Center where they will be presented to students during the second part of the ceremony. More on this special tradition: https://bit.ly/2QWO9XD

column1:
The latest message from President Bell ↓

Dear Students::: Faculty and Staff:

I know you join me in applauding the historic efforts of Coach Nate Oats and our men’s basketball team as they claimed the SEC regular season and tournament championships on their way to the NCAA Tournament Sweet 16. Congratulations::: as well::: to Coach Kristy Curry and the women’s basketball team for their first appearance in the NCAA tournament in over two decades. We also celebrate Coach Dana Duckworth and the gymnastics team for winning another SEC Championship; they will host the 2021 NCAA Gymnastics Regional this weekend in Coleman Coliseum. And::: UA runner Mercy Chelangat claimed an individual NCAA Cross Country Championship with the best individual finish in school history. Results like these leave no room for doubt; our student-athletes rank among the elite in the nation.

As our academic achievements attest::: our success extends well beyond the athletic arena. We are very proud of UA’s leadership in transformational education::: leading-edge research and inspirational service. The School of Law was recently ranked No. 25 on the list of best law graduate schools in the nation and ninth among public law schools for 2022 by U.S. News and World Report. Special recognition is also due for UA senior Kathleen McManus for being named PRWeek’s 2021 Outstanding Student; she credits faculty mentoring within UA’s Department of Advertising and Public Relations for much of her success. In addition::: please join me in honoring the three UA students who received a Critical Language Scholarship to study overseas this summer::: furthering their opportunities to contribute to the U.S. economy and to issues of national security.

As we move into April::: proud UA students and alumni will be receiving their class rings through a special ring ceremony::: an important tradition for conveying the Capstone spirit. From athletic triumphs to academic success::: The University of Alabama remains the place Where Legends Are Made.

Finally::: we continue to see low COVID-positive numbers and increasing vaccination rates::: supporting our plan to return to normal operations for the Fall 2021 Semester. Thank you for your continued vigilance in our ongoing efforts to protect our campus community.

Roll Tide!

Stuart R. Bell
President

column1:
Studying overseas during your college career can make a lifetime of a difference - and these three UA students are making it happen as recent recipients of the highly competitive Critical Language Scholarship! 👏 Congratulations to Jackson Burns::: Ann Williams and Samuel Watson!!

The Critical Language Scholarship is part of a U.S. State Department effort to expand the number of Americans studying and mastering critical foreign languages. This opportunity helps position students around the country to contribute to U.S. economic competitiveness and national security. Where Jackson::: Ann and Samuel will be studying this summer → https://bit.ly/3syh8Pn 🌏

If you know The University of Alabama::: you know we've firmly established our status as an institution of athletic champions - but we're a championship school beyond athletics::: too. 💯 With no shortage of championship-caliber programs and people::: our drive to be the best touches academics::: athletics and everything in between. From continued national recognition of multiple programs such as Advertising and Public Relations to National Merit Scholar enrollment to even our trees::: (we recently celebrated our fifth consecutive year as a Tree Campus USA!)::: you don't have to look far to find the champion spirit at UA.

We're a #ChampionshipSchool. It's what we do.
https://bit.ly/3ddFdo6 #WhereLegendsAreMade

column1:
Fewer than 10 faculty members in the University’s history have been honored with the recognition of Distinguished Research Professor - and Dr. David Albright is now one of those honorees! 👏 Dr. Albright is internationally recognized as a prolific and eminent scholar regarding military social work::: and as a thought leader in the area of veteran health and well-being. A leader in engaging and building healthier communities::: he currently holds the Hill Crest Foundation Endowed Chair in Mental Health Research in the UA School of Social Work. He directs the Office for Military Families and Veterans and is the principal investigator for the VitAL initiative.

Did you know: This title recognizes UA faculty who have achieved international accomplishments in their fields and who have been given extensive peer recognition for their scholarly contributions and noteworthy academic service.

More on Dr. Albright's work: https://bit.ly/3d8b4qy

column1: Our hearts are heavy as we think about the communities affected by the devastating tornadoes that tore through Alabama yesterday. For any of our students::: faculty or staff who may have been impacted::: we have resources available to you. UA students can apply for assistance through the Tide Together Student Support Fund (https://bamacares.sa.ua.edu/student-assistance/emergency-assistance/) and faculty/staff can contact Human Resources regarding the Employee Emergency Relief Fund.

With the impending threat of severe weather::: including the high risk of tornadoes and dangerous weather in West and Central Alabama::: normal UA operations will be suspended at noon today through 5 a.m. Friday. Employees who live in areas of higher risk are encouraged to leave earlier after consulting with their supervisors.

All classes::: including those conducted online or remotely are canceled as of noon. Libraries::: recreation centers and other campus facilities will close. Check the Bama Dining website for operating hours and locations.

Campus storm shelters will open if and when a tornado watch is issued by the National Weather Service::: and are available to all students::: faculty and staff::: including those who live off campus. Masks are required in all storm shelters and will be provided to those who don’t have one. During a tornado watch or warning::: students can use any legal parking in proximity to a shelter or refuge area.

When a tornado watch or warning is issued for the campus area::: a UA Alert will be sent. Make sure your contact information is updated in myBama to receive all UA Alerts.

While our normal severe weather guidelines and processes automatically trigger protocols during bad weather events::: the University is taking these actions early in anticipation of expected tornado watches and warnings today.

Please stay weather aware. Download the UA Safety app and follow @UA_Safety on Twitter for weather updates and other safety-related information. Information about severe weather affecting Tuscaloosa and UA is also available on 92.5 FM UA Info Radio.

Link to full message → https://bit.ly/39ffESD
More severe weather resources → https://bit.ly/3tQ7HLB

column1:
“Dr. Roach’s willingness to explore new research frontiers::: experiment with different writing mediums::: seek different reading audiences::: and regularly create exciting and enticing courses for our students demonstrates why she has been so successful in creating a perennially vigorous research program." - President Bell

Congratulations and Roll Tide to New College's Dr. Catherine Roach::: this year's recipient of the 2021 SEC Faculty Achievement Award winner for The University of Alabama! A professor of gender and cultural studies::: Dr. Roach is an internationally renowned scholar and recipient of numerous academic awards. Her impact at UA: http://bit.ly/3vPk6Bf

As we continue to celebrate Women's History Month::: we're putting the spotlight on some of UA's women of the media and communications who have made tremendous contributions through their storytelling and upholding truth and the public good. UA grad Betsy Plank was one of the many communications professionals who have made their mark on the world.

Did you know: Betsy Plank was known as a public relations pioneer::: a champion of PR education and the first lady of public relations. Throughout her career::: Plank achieved multiple firsts for women::: winning many top awards in the field. http://bit.ly/3tEoUYq

“After the rise of the COVID-19 pandemic::: our staff observed that while many organizations were addressing food insecurity::: there wasn’t a place that made families aware of the food resources available in their local communities."

A partnership between UA students and Auburn students is working to end child hunger in Alabama. How this project is helping to ensure that individuals in need can find food to feed their families → http://bit.ly/3l9MetT

“Winning an American Advertising Award is a very public acknowledgment of a student’s dedication and hard work. The competition is strong and the work has got to be good to win something at this level.”

The 2021 American Advertising Awards celebrated the outstanding work of students::: agencies::: corporations::: nonprofits::: universities and freelancers from Tuscaloosa and surrounding cities - including fourteen undergrad and two grad students from our College of Communication and Information Sciences!! 👏 Their impressive showing included taking home all four of the Judge’s Choice awards and the Best of Show award! 😮http://bit.ly/2OW2Hpu #WhereLegendsAreMade

It's almost that time of year - commencement ceremonies begin on April 30! Spring commencement exercises will be held at Coleman Coliseum over three days::: with more than 5:::000 graduates expected to be in attendance for nine ceremonies. All ceremonies will feature extensive safety protocols::: following the same model UA used to facilitate nine safe and successful commencement exercises last August. Information about ceremony times and dates::: along with information about physical distancing::: mask requirements and other safety protocols: http://bit.ly/3ltUKUK 🎓#BamaGrad

When a tornado watch or warning is issued for the campus area::: a UA Alert will be sent. Make sure your contact information is updated in myBama to receive all UA Alerts.

While our normal severe weather guidelines and processes automatically trigger protocols during bad weather events::: the University is taking these actions early in anticipation of expected tornado watches and warnings today.

Please stay weather aware. Download the UA Safety app and follow @UA_Safety on Twitter for weather updates and other safety-related information. Information about severe weather affecting Tuscaloosa and UA is also available on 92.5 FM UA Info Radio.

More information on preparing for severe weather: http://bit.ly/2NqbQGq

column1:
Highlights from Dr. Bell’s latest message ↓

I hope our students were able to take advantage of yesterday’s wellness/study day to recharge and prepare for the stretch run of the spring semester.

This past weekend many of our student-athletes were busy winning championships on the national stage. Our Adapted Athletics women’s basketball team registered its seventh national title since 2009. Our men’s basketball team topped a record-breaking regular season with an SEC Tournament title. Both the men’s and women’s teams have advanced to the NCAA Tournament with the men matching a program-best No. 2 seed while the women earned a spot in the Big Dance for the first time since 1999.

Congratulations are in order for Dr. David L. Albright::: who was recently recognized as a Distinguished Research Professor by the University of Alabama Board of Trustees. Dr. Albright is internationally recognized for his scholarly work regarding military social work and is regarded as a thought leader in the area of veteran health and well-being.

I’d like to congratulate and welcome our new Student Government Association executives led by incoming president Jill Fields. We look forward to working with you and the positive impact you will make on the Capstone.

We have made tremendous progress this spring and I remain grateful for your collective efforts to advance our mission and remain Tide Together.

Full message → http://bit.ly/PresidentBellMessageMarch16

column1:
"Service is one of the main principles at The University of Alabama. It is early::: it is a Saturday morning::: but we want to give back to the University as much as possible because they do so much for us."

This time last week::: UA students were volunteering around our community as part of the annual Hands On Tuscaloosa Day of Service! 👏 DYK: Bama Dining contributes to efforts to keep our Arboretum beautiful! 🌳Thank you to our students for making a difference last weekend!

"You must force yourself to be positive in the wake of setbacks."
Alabama Adapted athlete Peter Berry has a drive and passion that helped position him to play with the best - and now this freshman will be playing for a National Championship this weekend. How he faced tragedy and turned it into the opportunity to push forward and succeed ↓

Rick Karle WVTM 13
March 8 at 1:39 PM ·

The great news just keeps on coming for Crimson Tide athletics.
Yes::: Bama has reeled in the number one recruit in America.
He::: in fact is already enjoying his freshman year at the Capstone.
He will be playing for a national championship this weekend.

Star athletes such as DeVonta Smith and Najee Harris have departed.
John Petty and Herb Jones will soon be on their way out.
I'm here to tell you that the new BMOC is a strong::: handsome athlete from Houston.
An athlete that has not walked in nearly ten years.

This is the story about a tragedy.
It’s also the story about resiliency and success.
It’s a story about a 19-year-old who is educating the world.
It’s a story about Bama's next superstar.

Peter Berry lifts himself out of bed at 4:30 am.
There is work to do as he heads to team weight training at 5:30 am.
His brow sweats and his voice grunts as he gets after it.
He looks forward to breakfast::: then class::: then four hours of afternoon practice.

Peter Berry has needed that drive::: needed that passion.
It’s that drive and that passion that has brought him back from his darkest day.
It’s a day that Peter will never forget.
A day that came on July 2nd::: 2011 on a highway some 500 miles from his Texas house.

Josh and Robin Berry were the greatest parents ever.
Their three kids- Peter::: Aaron::: the little one::: Willa::: so precious::: so full of life.
Josh was a stern dad::: but oh::: how he loved his kids.
Josh and Robin had big plans for their kids::: who in 2011 were all under the age of ten.

They were in the home stretch of a wonderful trip to Colorado.
It happened in a flash as the distracted driver crossed lanes.
Life changed for Peter::: Aaron and the little one::: Willa.
Their parents were gone.
The children were rushed to a hospital::: clinging to life.

It was 2012::: and Uncle Matt and Aunt Simone were rooting for the children they had taken in.
They prayed for strength as Peter and Aaron were in rehab after their injuries::: both to the T-10 vertebrae.
Peter and Aaron were paralyzed from the waist down::: and the little one::: Willa::: had a long road back.
And as Matt and Simone loved their nephews and niece::: an amazing thing was about to happen

Peter Berry was only ten years old::: his brother a year younger.
A year removed from their darkest hour::: their hearts pumped as they arrived on the court.
Perhaps it offered Peter a way to release some aggression::: some pain.
Perhaps it took his mind off his darkest day.
The sport of wheelchair basketball had met its match.

For eight years::: he kept telling himself.
“The ability to overcome obstacles is mental.”
Peter Berry would develop his game and grind away.
Morning after morning of lifting weights.
Shot after shot after shot.

For eight years::: Peter Berry was angry::: happy::: sad::: hopeful.
It’s what drove him to become America’s top high school wheelchair basketball player.
Sore muscles::: calloused hands::: bruised arms.
And he wanted more.

More would come from the University Of Alabama.
The college known for winning national titles… in adapted athletics.
So as his cell phone lit up with offers from everywhere::: the kid from Houston signed his scholarship.
In January of 2020::: he was headed to Tuscaloosa- alone::: but intrigued.

Peter Berry tells me that the University Of Alabama has been a perfect fit.
Professors::: coaches::: teammates and students have been kind.
Oh::: and how he loves the southern hospitality.

It’s a big week for the university’s next superstar.
Peter and his teammates are working hard::: as the Alabama Adapted Athletics men’s wheelchair team will gun for another national title.
Coach Brent Hardin and the guys will host the national championship starting Friday.
First up for the Crimson Tide?
The Auburn Tigers.

The University Of Alabama’s next superstar is grinding on and teaching us all.
“You must force yourself to be positive in the wake of setbacks”::: Peter tells me.
“Expose yourself to positive books::: videos::: people. Negativity will only set you back.”

Just thinking about the future gets Peter Berry excited.
His younger brother Aaron will join him at UA next year.
His sister Willa? She’s attending boarding school in Colorado.
Uncle Matt and Aunt Simone reach out daily.

Nearly ten years after his darkest day::: Peter Berry is not looking behind::: but looking ahead.
Perhaps to the Paralympic games::: perhaps to settling down.
“I hope that my economics degree someday leads to a good job”::: says Peter.
“I’d like to get married and have a family.”

For now::: Peter Berry will continue to rise at 4:30 am::: working out::: going to class.

He continues to be a blessing to others.

He continues to represent the University Of Alabama with grace and class.

That::: my friend::: is Peter Berry.

The University Of Alabama’s next superstar.
#ShareTheGoodNews
*Pictures courtesy UA Athletics & Peter Berry
Alabama Football The University of Alabama Alabama Adapted Athletics #BuiltByBama #RollTide

“For us to be able to play in our own house at the Stran-Hardin Arena::: it really brings a tear to my eye thinking of how we have progressed::: and a smile to my face knowing we’re not done progressing.”

Alabama Adapted Athletics will host the Wheelchair Basketball National Championships on March 12-13! It’s not the first time UA has hosted the national championships - but it is the first time the games will be played on campus in Stran-Hardin Arena::: which opened in January 2018. Campus health + safety is a team effort! One way YOU can help us monitor and track any possible areas of coronavirus infection on campus? Participate in sentinel testing and encourage others to do their part to stomp out COVID-19. 💯 Did you know: As a thank you for your participation::: you'll receive a thank you gift or gift card! More details on recent changes ↓ Find more information at healthinfo.ua.edu
#TideTogether

“We can’t make this a better institution without students’ help.”
The University is inviting seniors + first-year students to help shape the future of the Capstone by participating in the National Survey of Student Engagement from March 1-May 15. The NSSE is a national survey that hundreds of colleges around the U.S. + Canada administer to their students to find out if those who engage in the educational experiences — courses::: co-curricular activities::: internships::: community engagement and undergraduate research — perform better.

This past weekend::: UA students participated in the Hands On Tuscaloosa Day of Service! 💯 This annual event gives our students the opportunity to get out and serve the local community::: making a positive impact in just a few short hours. column5:
A 26-year-old lady::: Panama sandra is lying critically ill at the University of Iganga::: Kampala Uganda. She needs radiotherapy to survive. Sandra is suffering from breast cancer and requires the sum of $8000 from kind-hearted people like you. to proceed to India for further treatment.

The cancer scourge reportedly started from her left breast::: which was ravaged until it was removed on doctor’s advice. Some respite came her way::: but it was not for long before the cancer virus came back with more venom. It has attacked the remaining breast and rapidly spreading all over her body. The radiotherapy treatment is to kill the cancer cells and prevent its spread Sandra::: a retailer of foodstuff::: and her husband who does frozen food business have exhausted their trading funds. They are pleading with Ugandans to help save the woman’s life from the scourge. Already they said::: the family has spent over 12 million shillings::: but the doctors have estimated that they would be needing more for her treatment.

Those that want to help Panama should contact her or her husband on +256 707889731.

Donations may also be sent to her huband's account at PostBank. The account name is:::Niwenyesiga Jackson and the account number::: 1030001019349.T
hankyou

Last week::: The University of Alabama System announced plans for a return to traditional in-person instruction without classroom capacity restrictions for the Fall 2021 Semester. As we plan for the fall::: we will continue to work with the UA System Health and Safety Task Force and monitor recommendations from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Alabama Department of Public Health to ensure the well-being of our entire UA community. And::: while we currently have a record low number of COVID-positive students::: faculty and staff::: continuing to follow recommended safety measures is essential for our ongoing progress.

A reminder for our students: As you continue to prioritize your academic focus this semester::: don’t forget Monday::: March 15::: is a non-instructional wellness and study day. It’s important to set aside time to rest and reflect so you can recharge and finish the semester strong.

Highlights from President Bell's latest message to campus ↓

With an ongoing emphasis on testing and the continuation of our vaccine distribution::: we have seen a steady decline in positive COVID-19 cases. Because of the talented staff at our Student Health Center and University Medical Center::: symptomatic and exposure testing continue to run smoothly and remain available for everyone in our UA community.

The Student Health Center’s medical professionals have dedicated long hours to serving our students over the past year::: providing a skilled standard of care that has been both indispensable and impressive. I sincerely appreciate their servant leadership.

This week we continue our celebration of Black History Month. Please make time to visit the Diversity::: Equity and Inclusion website to review the special programming to showcase African American culture and to support our path forward as an accepting::: inclusive community. Join me in honoring the many black students::: alumni::: faculty and staff who have positively shaped UA’s history and legacy by learning more about their contributions and accomplishments.

Our legendary faculty and alumni contribute to our communities and the world with a pioneering impact on projects beyond the realm of our planet. Our revolutionary work as leaders in research::: service and teaching continues in earnest and with unrivaled excellence.

Students::: I hope you will continue to set and pursue SMART goals to aid your focus on academic success. Learning is a lifelong process::: and our dedicated faculty and staff are here to walk beside you on the journey toward a remarkable future.

Stay healthy; stay warm; and stay Tide Together. You make me proud.

See the full message → https://bit.ly/3s75fzu

The University of Alabama has canceled classes and suspended normal operations all day today::: Tuesday::: Feb. 16. Campus offices::: libraries::: recreation centers and medical centers will all remain closed::: as will the Gadsden campus.

Check the Bama Dining website for operating hours and locations. COVID testing appointments will be rescheduled.

Stay safe and take extra precautions during the extreme cold and icy road conditions. The Alabama Department of Transportation has strongly advised motorists not to travel except in case of emergency.

Follow @UA_Safety on Twitter for weather updates and other safety-related information. For more information on what to do during a severe weather event::: visit the Office of Emergency Management’s website.

The University of Alabama will delay classes and operations until 10:30 a.m. tomorrow::: Feb. 16::: due to the ongoing threat of icy roads and severe weather. The delay::: which also applies to the Gadsden campus::: cancels in-person and remote classes scheduled before 10:30 a.m. and pushes back the opening of campus offices.

Recreation centers::: campus libraries::: University Medical Center and the Student Health Center will delay opening. Check the Bama Dining website for operating hours and locations. COVID testing appointments will be rescheduled.

Campus safety officials will continue to evaluate weather and road conditions and issue an update at 8:30 a.m. tomorrow. Any changes will be shared at that time. Please continue to monitor your email and follow @UA_Safety on Twitter for updates.

For more information on what to do during a severe weather event::: visit the Office of Emergency Management’s website.

column1: This week we recognize the 65th anniversary of Autherine Lucy Foster’s enrollment as the first African American student to integrate The University of Alabama campus. Her noble sense of justice fostered change throughout American society::: influencing positive transformation across our state and nation.

column1:
Message from President Bell ↓

Today our nation bears witness to the presidential inauguration::: a tradition that began in 1789 as a symbolic gesture to endorse our democratic processes. During this day of transition::: I encourage you to reflect on our freedoms::: opportunities and responsibilities as citizens of the United States of America. I am thankful to live in a nation where its people have the ability to participate in a democratic process and to change lives and better society through education.

I am also grateful to be at The University of Alabama::: where caring for one another is part of our culture. I appreciate all of you who are continuing to follow our health and safety guidelines. Testing remains an important component of our plan to reduce virus spread in our community. Your vigilance and participation in our testing programs are greatly appreciated.

We persist in adding highly qualified and innovative leaders to our renowned faculty. Selma native Dr. Schnavia Smith Hatcher was selected to lead our School of Social Work::: and her leadership will further secure the School’s nationwide ranking.

Congratulations to senior Caroline Yuk::: one of 46 recipients in the U.S. to receive the esteemed Marshall Scholarship. This marks the first time a UA student has received the award in more than 40 years.

To celebrate the life and legacy of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.::: the Division of Diversity::: Equity and Inclusion has facilitated multiple events::: including a day of virtual service. We remain inspired by Dr. King’s leadership and vision as we continue our quest to build a diverse::: accepting and inclusive community at the Capstone.

As we lean into a new semester::: we can all be optimistic about the days ahead. At UA::: our standard has always been one of excellence in everything we do. I challenge you to embrace that standard::: unite as a community and continue to help and support one another as we fulfill our mission of teaching::: research and service.

Full message → https://emailtemplates.ua.edu/president/a-message-from-the-president-22/

Looking for ways to celebrate the life and legacy of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.? UA's Division of Diversity::: Equity and Inclusion has compiled a list of upcoming events - including::: A Conversation with Michael Eric Dyson for the annual Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. lecture.

Dyson is lauded as one of the world’s premier intellectuals on the subjects of race::: religion and contemporary culture. He recently was named Distinguished University Professor of African American and Diaspora Studies::: Distinguished University Professor of Ethics and Society and Centennial Professor at Vanderbilt University.

Join us for his lecture on Thursday::: Jan. 28::: at 6 p.m. via Zoom. Key themes he’ll address are cultural and social aspects that have shaped the U.S. in regard to race::: the genealogy of anti-blackness and how the U.S. has confronted systemic racism. Registration is required to attend the lecture.

Update: This event has reached full capacity. See the other events hosted by UA's Division of Diversity::: Equity and Inclusion → https://diversity.ua.edu/celebrating-the-life-and-legacy-of-the-rev-dr-martin-luther-king-jr-2021/
