column1:
Important Sentinel Testing Information ↓

To help prevent the spread of coronavirus::: COVID-19 sentinel testing of campus community members will continue in Spring 2021::: with more frequent testing scheduled the first three weeks of the semester.

Beginning this semester::: all sentinel testing will be managed through UA medical facilities::: so registration is no longer required. Participants will receive incentives like Starbucks or Bama Cash gift cards::: or other items.

Sentinel testing captures a random sampling of students::: faculty and staff to help monitor the prevalence of COVID-19 so UA can respond promptly to outbreaks or increases in infection rates.

Participation in sentinel testing is voluntary for most::: but required for:
- Students living on campus.
- Students participating in clinical activities::: who will have a presence on campus at any time during the semester.
- Other individuals participating in University-sponsored programs::: at the discretion of UA.

Because sentinel testing is one of several important measures for preventing the spread of the coronavirus and keeping campus safe::: voluntary participation is strongly encouraged.

If randomly selected::: individuals will receive an email from the COVID-19 Support Program with instructions. Participants will choose a time and location to take the test conveniently::: confidentially::: and at no cost. A PCR test with a short nasal swab will be self-administered under observation::: and results returned within 72 hours.

More about Spring 2021 sentinel testing → https://news.ua.edu/2021/01/sentinel-testing-continues-in-spring-2021-with-improvements/
Happy first day of spring semester! It's been a minute since you've been here...let's reintroduce you to some familiar faces you might see around campus. 😉

Message from President Bell ↓

Today is the first day of the Spring semester::: and I am delighted to welcome you home to Tuscaloosa and to your campus community. A new semester is always exciting – an opportunity full of promise and possibility.

What better way to begin than by claiming our hard-earned position as national champions! Monday night’s victory accentuates the continued excellence and integrity of our program. Congratulations to our outstanding student-athletes::: Coach Nick Saban and our skilled coaching staff for a triumphant season. I am proud of how they represented the University both on and off the field.

The gatherings that followed the game underscore the need for continued vigilance and caution by every member of our community. For this reason::: we have given faculty and students the flexibility for remote learning for the next two weeks.

Our faculty and staff have worked very hard to prepare for a successful spring. Despite the unique challenges we faced in the fall::: we persisted and prevailed in finishing the semester and celebrating our graduates. We must continue our combined efforts to protect each other and stay healthy. We have hindsight to inform us::: and medical experts who continue to advise us on how to remain safely on campus for the spring semester. I implore you to continue to do your part. Stay vigilant and follow the important health and safety standards we have in place.

Student::: faculty and staff testing will increase this spring::: including sentinel::: exposure::: symptomatic and for-cause testing. Through comprehensive testing::: we will continue to reduce virus spread and provide prompt support for those who may become infected. The health and well-being of our community remain our highest priority.

Faculty and staff::: as our students pursue their interests in our state-of-the-art facilities with your support and expertise::: I remain grateful for your continued commitment. You play an essential role in their experiences and success::: and your contributions to our mission are crucial.

It is going to be another great semester at The University of Alabama. Welcome back – and::: of course::: ROLL TIDE!

Full message → https://emailtemplates.ua.edu/president/message-from-the-president-67/

column1:
Message from Dr. Pope::: VP for Student Life ↓

We are very proud of our football program as it prepares to play in the National Championship this evening. Our players and coaches have remained dedicated to the process and have overcome many adversities with class and passion.

Our students have also demonstrated a high level of dedication and perseverance during this unprecedented time. As you prepare to return to campus::: it is important to remain focused on doing your part to keep our community safe. Whether cheering on the team live in Miami::: in Tuscaloosa or elsewhere::: please remember:
- Wear your mask.
- Avoid parties or any large gatherings and stay 6 feet away from others.
- Make smart decisions before::: during and after the game. Any unlawful behavior and/or violations of our health and safety protocols will result in disciplinary action.
- Be a good neighbor and respect the impact your actions may have on those around you.

As a reminder::: no in-person events are permitted for any student organizations during the first two weeks of the semester.

At UA::: we are fortunate to have many successes to celebrate::: and we expect our students to do so responsibly and safely. Please set the example with safety::: passion and class.

Roll Tide! More information → healthinfo.ua.edu/championship

Capstone College of Nursing is excited to officially open its new building expansion today! The proposed three-story::: over 30:::000-square-foot building expansion will significantly impact the College’s ability to support more highly qualified students in achieving their dreams of becoming professional nurses.

The expansion includes a home health care lab suite::: additional practicum lab space::: on-site food service::: additional quiet study areas::: collaborative work carrels::: private space for academic and career advising and an over 2:::000-square-foot outdoor terrace that will greatly improve the student experience! See more from today's ribbon cutting ↓

Students attending class on campus for the Spring 2021 semester must complete a new::: two-part COVID-19 online training module prior to or immediately upon return to campus. The training is now available via the UA LMS button located on the Campus Life tab in myBama. Check your Crimson email for additional info. computer.

column1:
Important Spring Semester Update from Dr. Bell ↓

Happy New Year! I hope you have remained healthy and are well rested following winter break.

Congratulations to DeVonta Smith on winning the Heisman Trophy last night as the most outstanding player in college football! We are very proud of DeVonta and the entire football program for the way they have represented Alabama and look forward to cheering them on in the National Championship!

Our team is working hard to prepare for your return to campus::: meeting often over the holidays::: reviewing plans and monitoring COVID-19 trends in our community. We continue to receive guidance from the UA System Health and Safety Task Force::: and with their support::: campus operations will resume on Jan. 7 with adjusted or staggered work schedules and classes on Jan. 13.

A thorough review of our fall testing and contact tracing data confirmed our health and safety protocols kept campus locations such as classrooms and common areas safe. As we return to campus life::: we must all remain vigilant in following our health and safety protocols::: including masking and social distancing.

To continue to maintain a safe campus in the spring::: we have enhanced a few aspects of our plans:

- Students living on campus will be required to test within seven days of their return to campus.
- COVID testing will be conducted by University Medical Center and Student Health Center staff.
- Testing for our entire campus community will increase::: including sentinel testing.
- Exposure::: symptomatic and for-cause testing will continue as in the fall.
- Spring semester will begin with a two-week moratorium on all student events.

Details of our spring plans are posted at healthinfo.ua.edu. Please visit this site regularly for the most up-to-date information and important campus announcements.

Thank you again for all that you do as part of our community::: and we look forward to having you back.

#TideTogether:::
Stuart R. Bell
President

“I consider it a privilege to even get to go to school and learn::: and then to throw in the prestige of The University of Alabama::: a place I grew up loving and is just in my blood. I’m just thankful God provided a way.”

From being the first in her family to go to college::: to spending years traveling to the far ends of the world serving those in need::: Leigh Mayberry has lived a life full of ambition and adventure. This past semester::: she checked another item off her bucket list when she graduated from UA::: earning a bachelor’s degree in nursing. Read more about how Leigh plans to use her experiences to inspire and motivate others. → https://news.ua.edu/2020/12/a-life-of-adventure-and-a-heart-for-service/

This holiday season::: with more people shopping from home due to the pandemic::: millions of packages will find their way to front porches::: doorsteps + apartment lobbies.
Here are a few tips to help make sure your packages end up with you! ↓
📲 Track your package
🙋‍♀️ Get help from your neighbors
🏡 Tell the delivery service where to leave your package
🚚 Have packages delivered elsewhere
📷Install a doorbell or security camera
For more tips → http://bit.ly/372k2DU
column3: Also::: if you have a package that may be on your porch and no one home::: please feel free to call your property manager. We’ll be happy to go over and set them inside

column1:
Over the break::: I hope you will rest::: relax and celebrate the many ways we prevailed the last year. I am deeply grateful for all you have contributed to our success. Last week::: I shared my pride and gratitude with our students for all they have achieved this year. Likewise::: I could not have asked for a more caring::: dedicated and supportive group of professionals than the faculty and staff who serve the students on this campus. It is an honor to work with you.

Wherever you are this holiday season::: Susan and I wish you all the very best. Be safe::: be blessed and Roll Tidings! ❤️

Full message from Dr. Bell → https://emailtemplates.ua.edu/president/message-from-the-president-65/

The Student Health Center and Pharmacy will be open from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday-Thursday::: and 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. on Friday for the remainder of the semester + will not hold evening or weekend clinic hours. The SHCP will close at 5 p.m. on Dec. 18 for the winter break::: and reopen on Thursday::: Jan. 7::: 2021::: at 8 a.m.

Students are encouraged to call the Student Health Center and Pharmacy to ensure they have medication refills set up with their home pharmacy while UA observes winter break. Students should call 205-348-6276 and speak with the pharmacy to forward their prescriptions to their home pharmacy. 💊
For more info visit → https://shc.sa.ua.edu

Exit testing for students will continue at the East Campus Storm Shelter from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. December 8 - 11. Students should schedule an appointment for testing online + bring their ACT card::: CWID and driver’s license or government-issued ID. 😷

From Dec. 14 - 18::: all exit testing for students will be at the Student Health Center and Pharmacy. Students should call 205-348-6262 or 205-348-0386 to schedule an appointment. Testing will end each day at 4 p.m. Students who need an exit test for traveling should observe the testing requirements of their airline to make sure they are within the designated time frame required for the test to be valid. ✈️

To schedule an appointment online → https://bit.ly/UAScheduleAnAppointment
For more information → https://bit.ly/StudentCOVIDTestingInfo

Watching Bama beat Tigers is fun.

-Game won and huge spread covered. ✅
-Most points scored by Bama against LSU. ✅
-First team to ever win 9 SEC regular season games (Could clinch record of 10 next week). ✅
-SEC West Champs clinched for a record 13th time. ✅
-Extended FBS record of scoring at least 35 points to 22 games. ✅
-Extended overall winning record against LSU to 54-26-5 and winning in Baton Rouge to 29-9-2. ✅
-Extended and set SEC record of consecutive conference games scoring at least 40 points to 8 games. ✅
-Devonta Smith extended SEC record of TD catches to 38. ✅
-Najee Harris extended 2020 rushing TD FBS lead to 20. ✅
-97 consecutive victories over unranked teams -\-\ the longest such streak in FBS history since the AP Poll began in 1936. ✅
-Extended FBS record of winning game while ranked as AP #1 to 94.
-Dominated and put the LSU head coach in his one and done place. ✅

UA students: You made it to the final day of classes! We know 2020 was a challenging year::: but you persevered! Now is the time to finish strong on your finals. Here are some tips from our tutors::: peer coaches::: and student leaders to help you through finals week:
🗓 Stay organized by keeping a calendar/agenda for your study time + your exam schedule. Making plans helps you stay on track.
⏰ Begin studying for finals as soon as possible::: and develop a study plan to make sure you have time to cover everything.
😴 The end of the semester can be very stressful. Find time to take breaks and relax so that your mind is in the right place.
For more tips for finals week → https://bit.ly/UAFinalsWeekTips

UA community: Looking for some socially distanced fun? Now through February 2021::: you can explore the beautiful + dangerous North through the stories and accomplishments of the past at the Mildred Westervelt Warner Transportation Museum's Winter Exhibit: Chronicles of the Arctic Circle. Sanitation of all art materials will take place throughout the day to comply with COVID-19 safety protocols. Don't forget your mask! ❄️
For dates + information → https://bit.ly/WinterExhibitEvent

column1: Did you know UA offers a free online mental health screening? All responses are completely anonymous and confidential. Brief screenings are the quickest way to determine if you or someone you care about should connect with a behavioral health professional. Behavioral health is a key part of your overall well-being. To learn more + get started → https://bit.ly/33vlmwP

Did you know: Flu shots are FREE to students::: faculty and staff + spouses; insurance is not required. 💉 Employees and students must have their CWID. Faculty and staff can visit the Faculty-Staff Clinic at University Medical Center for their free flu shot::: and students can visit the Student Health Center. 👍

Before the Iron Bowl happens tomorrow::: student veteran support groups from both universities came together earlier in the week to bring awareness to veteran suicide. The third annual Operation Iron Ruck began in Auburn on Nov. 25 and will end in Tuscaloosa ahead of the Iron Bowl on Nov. 28.

During their three-day trip::: the student veterans from UA and Auburn carry 22 pounds of materials to be donated to a Birmingham-based nonprofit organization that assists homeless military veterans in transition from life on the streets into a self-sustained lifestyle.
More details on Operation Iron Ruck → https://news.ua.edu/2020/11/veteran-suicide-awareness-focus-of-operation-iron-ruck/

“The kids are having a great time. The mentorship is still occurring and the impact is still there::: which is just really inspiring to see.”

Al’s Pals::: a traditionally in-person mentoring program that recruits more than 1:::000 UA students each year to mentor local elementary school children::: has persevered through the pandemic to continue offering students help with their homework as well as participation in enrichment and recreational activities virtually. 👏 For more on how Al's Pals is thriving despite COVID-19 restrictions. → https://bit.ly/AlsPals

For the past six years three members of the Carrasquilla family have carried on two family traditions: attending UA + giving to those in need. In partnership with Bama Dining::: they created the Swipe Away Hunger program. This program allows UA students the chance to donate their unused meal plan meals so they can be made into Thanksgiving meals for those in need in the West Alabama community.
For more about how these students are leaving a legacy by giving back→ https://bit.ly/UASwipeAwayHunger

November 19::: 2020 at 1:55 PM ·

The University of Alabama United Way 2020 Campaign Celebration

Highlights from Dr. Bell’s latest message ↓

- The eyes of the world were on our university and the University of Alabama System when we announced our goal of opening safely in August. Many institutions around the country followed our model::: and once again our people led by example.
- A robust testing program has served as a critical component to our success this semester. University Medical Center::: the Student Health Center and our campus partners have administered more than 80:::000 tests over the past four months.
- As a reminder: free exit testing is available for students at Coleman Coliseum. Scheduling an exit test is a smart::: practical way to protect you::: your family and your hometown community. Appointments will fill quickly::: so please schedule your free test as soon as possible.
- The work of the Presidential Advisory Committee for Diversity::: Equity and Inclusion::: led by Dr. Christine Taylor and her team::: has been another signal achievement of 2020. They produced a comprehensive report that will be an essential guide star for our continued progress.
- At a time when public health dominates the global spotlight::: we are pleased to share the news that Dr. Heather Carter-Templeton::: a professor in the Capstone College of Nursing::: has been inducted into the American Academy of Nursing 2020 Class of Fellows.

“My family and I are deeply thankful for the faculty::: staff and students here at the Capstone. Our faculty have risen to the occasion and developed innovative instruction methods to connect with students. The transformational educational opportunities for which we are known are changing lives::: and our stature as a leader among research universities continues to soar. Best wishes for safe travels and good health during the holiday season.”

Full message → https://emailtemplates.ua.edu/president/a-message-from-the-president-21/

column1:
Each UA student is offered one free exit test as they leave for Thanksgiving and winter holidays. An appointment is required::: and available time slots are filling up fast. Students should schedule their appointment to meet travel needs.

Students need to be sure to research testing requirements for airlines or travel destinations::: which may include a negative test::: and plan to schedule an exit test accordingly. Exit tests provided on campus are “rapid” or antigen tests that offer results quickly. If a PCR test is required for travel::: students must find it from another source. Students are required to bring their ACT card::: CWID and government-issued ID to their exit test.
More info → https://healthinfo.ua.edu/testing-information/student-testing/

UA’s President’s Advisory Committee for Diversity::: Equity and Inclusion released its comprehensive report::: “Path Forward:::” which includes strategies for ongoing coordination and expansion of UA’s DEI efforts. The report builds on the University’s strategic plan goal to enrich learning and work environments by providing an accepting::: inclusive community that attracts and supports a diverse faculty::: staff and student body.

“I am proud of the thoughtful work of this committee to actively identify practices that will enhance the UA experience for all students::: faculty and staff:::” said President Stuart R. Bell. “This is personal and critical for me::: and it strengthens our campus-wide commitment to fostering a culture of inclusivity.”

The committee of faculty::: staff and students focused on:
- Increasing and retaining underrepresented students::: faculty and staff
- Enhancing the campus community to help them thrive
- Providing opportunities to develop cultural competencies
- Implementing the recommendations

The preliminary report was presented to Bell in late September::: and progress has already been seen on campus. The University launched enhanced diversity student recruitment efforts with new multicultural visitation and orientation programs this summer::: and opened its updated and enhanced Intercultural Diversity Center on the second floor of the Ferguson Center in October.

More information: https://bit.ly/3lALWeU

Sentinel testing is a random sampling of all asymptomatic students::: faculty and staff to understand the underlying prevalence of infection on campus so UA can respond promptly to outbreaks or increases in infection rates. column1: According to this week’s dashboard release::: the UA System COVID testing results remain minimal over the last seven days. “We’ve noticed::: in general::: of the students coming to the University that they have a desire to serve. The Center for Service and Leadership has continued to grow with that desire of students coming to campus.”

Hands On Tuscaloosa Day of Serving provides UA students the opportunity to get connected to the Tuscaloosa community through service. column1:
In case you missed it: We kicked off our annual United Way campaign last Thursday! The 2020 campaign has gone virtual::: but the need remains real. This year’s campaign has a goal of $400:::000 and is more important than ever as United Way supports the community during the COVID-19 pandemic. The organization’s West Alabama Community Response Fund is assisting residents impacted by COVID-19.

More info for #UA faculty + staff: https://bit.ly/UAUnitedWayHQ

"I am very encouraged by the trends regarding COVID-19 cases on our campus and I am optimistic about finishing the fall semester together and returning for the spring semester with increased in-person learning and community opportunities. I am extremely grateful for the enduring commitment demonstrated by our faculty::: staff::: students and their families during these challenging times. That commitment and resilience has allowed us to continue to be on our campus and to now look forward to an engaging spring semester." - President Bell

We're just 60 days away from Fall commencement ceremonies::: and the semester is rolling right along. From the upcoming virtual Fall Campus Assembly to the Premier Awards - the highest honors given at the Capstone - to the launch of the annual Beat Auburn Beat Hunger campaign::: we have a busy few weeks ahead! More from President Bell::: including a mention of game day guidelines for our fans with tickets who will be attending this weekend's football game vs. Georgia → http://bit.ly/DrBellMessageOct12 #TideTogether

column1: As we wrap up Thank a Donor Week::: we hope you felt the positive impact you are making in the lives of our students. Your philanthropic support has inspired our students to give back::: and for that::: we are grateful. #ThanksAndRollTide

For Thank a Donor Week::: appreciation tags can be found across campus to display what has been made possible by UA donors. Barbara and Cris Stone are avid supporters of the College of Arts and Sciences and recently named the band storage room::: a climate-controlled space of lockers and shelving for the Million Dollar Band. In addition::: the Stones have created endowments to further provide program support and scholarships for our students. Thank you::: Barbara and Cris! #ThanksAndRollTide

The annual Beat Auburn Beat Hunger campaign launched a week ago!! 🎉 BABH competes with the Beat Bama food drive at Auburn University::: and together they’ve raised more than 7 million pounds of food over the past 26 years. DYK: UA has won the competition for three years in a row::: last year collecting 278:::788 pounds of food. 💯 This year's on-campus drive will focus solely on collecting funds::: with collection barrels not on campus but placed instead around Tuscaloosa. More info: http://bit.ly/2020BABHLaunch

*Photo taken pre-pandemic in 2019

Each autumn::: The University of Alabama’s faculty and staff join together in support of the United Way of West Alabama and its 26 partner agencies. This year's campaign will run through mid-November. Watch the campaign kickoff today at 2pm on the College of Communication and Information Sciences’ Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/UACCIS

For more info: http://communityaffairs.ua.edu/2020-ua-united-way-headquarters/

column1:
The latest message from Dr. Myron Pope::: VP for Student Life::: to our #UA students + families ↓

"We have made great progress these past few weeks as we have worked together to control the spread of COVID-19."

Last week::: we were able to restore some student organization events::: allowing students more opportunities to connect with one another::: our campus::: and our community.

Parents::: please see our calendar of programs and services for ways your student can safely connect with their peers this semester::: including information from University Programs::: a student-led organization that has been working harder than ever to develop and host student programming that fosters community while meeting all safety protocols and guidelines:

-Engagement Pods: https://up.sa.ua.edu/up-engage/engagement-pods/
-University Programs Calendar: https://up.sa.ua.edu/events/category/up-engage/list/
-University Recreation Hours::: Classes::: Rentals: https://urec.sa.ua.edu/
-Student Involvement: https://studentinvolvement.sa.ua.edu/
-Counseling Center: https://counseling.sa.ua.edu/

First year and transfer students can connect directly with our office of First Year Experience for one-on-one peer mentoring::: community building programs::: First Year Hangout Hour::: and more.

"I urge you to continue to do your part to protect those around you by wearing your mask::: practicing physical distancing::: and avoiding large gatherings. Let’s remain committed to the process so we can achieve our goal of finishing the semester together on campus."
For full message: http://bit.ly/VPSLMessageOct7

column1: Weekly student positives dropped by 50% on the UA campus for the fourth successive week::: down from 846 the week of August 28 to 24 this week. 888 students at The University of Alabama were tested this week. Preventive health measures::: careful enforcement of event restrictions and robust testing produced another significant decline in positive COVID-19 cases throughout The University of Alabama System for the week ending October 1. “We will continue to closely monitor our entire testing platform to assure accurate reporting of all positive cases:::” said Dr. Richard Friend::: Dean of UA’s College of Community Health Sciences. Dr. Friend said isolation housing remains at less than 2% occupied. For the full release and dashboard visit uasystem.edu/covid-19-dashboard.

Have a ticket to tomorrow's home football game? 🏈 Don't forget to tune in to 92.5 FM #UA Info Radio while you're in Tuscaloosa! 👍 It's going to be a beautiful day for some Alabama football and 92.5 FM is the place to get updates on weather::: traffic and game day information. 💯 #RollTide

If you have tickets to attend the home opener this weekend::: make sure to review what's new to the 2020 #UA Gameday experience. 🏈 Please note things will be different this football season in light of the pandemic. See the changes we're implementing in order to comply with CDC::: state of Alabama::: NCAA and SEC health guidelines to keep fans safe while preventing the spread of coronavirus: http://bit.ly/2020UAGamedayExperience 🐘 #TideTogether

column1:
“I am proud of your continued commitment to our mission and remain grateful for your support. Tide Together::: we will persist and prevail.”

President Bell provided the following updates in his weekly email:

- For the third successive week::: positive COVID cases at the University have dropped dramatically: https://uasystem.edu/covid-19-dashboard/

- Last week we saw a 60 percent decrease in student positives and record lows in occupancy of our isolation/quarantine space.

- Effective today::: and with safety measures in place::: UA student organizations can begin hosting non-social engagement events that support their mission.

- Class schedules for spring will be published next week and we have recently announced a modified spring academic calendar. First and foremost::: we will see greater in-class learning opportunities for students across the board and on-campus residence will continue as normal in the spring.

- This weekend our 2020 game day protocols will enable us to provide a safe and enjoyable experience for all fans visiting Bryant Denny Stadium. Whether enjoying a watch party from home or cheering from the stands::: it will be an exciting afternoon of SEC football: https://bit.ly/2020UAGamedayExperience

For additional details::: please see the full message at: http://bit.ly/PresidentBellMessageOct1

We all have a role to play in keeping our campus as healthy as possible! Sentinel testing is one of the many strategies utilized by #UA to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Faculty and staff should use their myBama login information to sign up with Verily::: and students should use their crimson email login. Details on who is required or eligible to participate::: what to do if you get selected and more ↓ Questions? Call 205-348-2819 or email testing@guidesafe.org.

More info for faculty and staff: bit.ly/3krl7c5

More info for students: https://bit.ly/321jHxv

Important info on Spring 2021 academic calendar:

-Classes will begin Wednesday::: Jan. 13::: a week later than previously scheduled to provide 12 days between New Year’s Day and initial classroom meetings.

-Spring break will be canceled for continuous learning to mitigate risks associated with travel.

-The last day for students to add/drop classes without a “W” is Wednesday::: Jan. 20.

-Classes will be canceled on Monday::: March 15::: as a wellness/study day mid-semester::: but offices will remain open.

Classes will look much the same as they do this semester::: with the majority having an in-person component and remote options in case a student or faculty member needs to quarantine or isolate.

Additional information::: including holiday information for faculty and staff and spring semester health and safety protocols: http://bit.ly/UASpringSemesterChanges2021

column1:
The latest message from Dr. Pope::: vice president for Student Life ↓

Beginning October 1::: student organizations may host non-social engagement events that support their mission and business operations.

-Examples of events that are permitted include: organizational business meetings::: community service::: recreational activities::: academic study groups::: religious gatherings::: sister/brotherhood events::: intake/recruitment::: initiation::: community-building events::: limited philanthropy events (approved on a case-by-case basis::: see below).

-Very limited off-campus activities may be approved.

Please note that in-person student social events are still NOT permitted including:
-Parties::: band parties::: swaps::: day parties::: and date parties.
-Philanthropy events with social event elements (amplified music including bands and DJs::: cookouts::: etc.).-In-person events of any kind on Saturdays of home Alabama Football games.

For information regarding planning & hosting events::: as well as guidelines for events::: please see Dr. Pope’s full message here: http://bit.ly/VPStudentLifeMessageSept29

Masks::: social distancing::: and all policies outlined in the Social Event Guidelines Addendum must be strictly followed.

We expect all student organizations to take the utmost care to protect the health and safety of your members and our community. Please contact our Office of Student Involvement with questions.

We're taking many steps to help stop the spread of COVID-19 - including comprehensive testing on campus. Helpful testing reminders for students::: faculty + staff↓

-Testing for students who are symptomatic or have been exposed is 8 a.m. – 5 p.m. each weekday at Coleman Coliseum. *

-Testing for employees who are symptomatic or have been exposed is 8 a.m. – 3:45 p.m. each weekday at University Medical Center. *

-The Student Health Center is open for drive-thru testing on the weekend from 11 a.m. – 2 p.m. *

-Sentinel testing is conducted weekly for a randomized selection of the student::: faculty & staff populations. *

-For-cause testing in geographic areas or groups continues as determined by UA health officials.

More information: healthinfo.ua.edu 👍#TideTogether
* Appointment required

column1:
The most recent message to our students from Dr. Pope::: VP for Student Life ↓

Our numbers for testing continue to improve and I remain grateful for your vigilant attention to campus policies helping us curb the spread of COVID-19. It is imperative we all continue to follow our UA Health and Safety Guidelines as we strive to complete a safe fall semester: http://bit.ly/HealthSafetyGuidelines

The moratorium on in-person gatherings remains in effect. However::: because of your commitment to halting the spread of COVID-19::: I am pleased to share the following changes::: effective Monday::: Sept. 14:

-Campus study spaces in residential areas are eligible to be opened.
-Dining rooms will be opened with strict adherence to safety guidelines.
-Colleges and departments can begin to host in-person events that follow the previous limitations for a maximum of 50 people inside and 100 people outside. Events must be submitted for approval through the appropriate VP or dean’s office.
-Students who live in the same residence hall may visit each other’s rooms::: provided: (1) masks are worn; (2) social distancing is strictly observed; and (3) each resident is limited to one guest at a time.

Social distancing::: mask wearing::: and other health and safety protocols must be strictly observed in all of these environments. Student-organized gatherings and events remain prohibited at this time.

The gradual loosening of moratorium restrictions will continue to be evaluated as we move forward. With your continued cooperation::: and as our numbers for testing and student conduct cases continue to improve::: we will consider longer-term plans for the semester. We must stay the course and continue to follow the health and safety protocols set forth in the Return to Full Operations Plan.

We have listened and responded to your concerns about evolving our policies to create the healthiest learning environment possible. I hope the changes outlined above demonstrate our continued commitment to your academic success and creating a more engaged and safe campus for all.

Thank you again as we all do our part to stay Tide Together.

Sincerely:::
Dr. Myron Pope
Vice President for Student Life

"The new look for the homepage is the tip of the iceberg. Underneath is a complete re-engineering of the University’s web environment for the entire campus::: all built within the WordPress platform.”

ICYMI: UA.edu has a brand new look! 💯 The new design aligns the homepage with other recruitment::: branding and marketing efforts; enhances compliance with web accessibility standards; and provides new::: dynamic ways to uplift campus partners. How this fresh design tells more of our story in a strategic::: creative and modern way → http://bit.ly/NewHomepage2020

Q: Is #UA Healthcheck mandatory?
A: Yes!! ✅

All faculty::: staff and students working on campus are required to truthfully complete UA Healthcheck on a daily basis. We are using this tool to reduce the risk of further exposure to COVID-19. This site informs public health and university officials about emerging symptom hot spots and helps prioritize participants who might need COVID-19 testing. Learn more: https://www.ua.edu/healthcheck/about

“The Cahaba River is one of the richest::: most biodiverse rivers in the world.”

Local artist Caleb O'Connor::: the sculptor behind Minerva at Manderson Landing::: has created a 27'x12' mural in the Great Hall of the Ferguson Center to spotlight the beauty + biodiversity of the Cahaba River. Why he chose to feature the Cahaba lily → http://bit.ly/CahabaMural

"The health and safety of our community is our top priority and we will use every resource available to assist with testing::: education and enforcement. Thank you for your commitment::: patience and resiliency in the face of these challenges as they are making a difference."

Today's message from President Bell shared a few updates regarding COVID-19 ↓

-For our students who test positive and prepare to move to campus isolation space::: staffing and medical resources have been enhanced to ensure prompt communication and expanded services.

-The COVID19 hotline (205-348-2819) has been upgraded to speed the delivery of answers to your questions. The UA healthinfo website is another good resource: healthinfo.ua.edu

-A key component of our plan::: sentinel testing for asymptomatic students::: faculty and staff::: began yesterday and will continue weekly. Participation is required for all students who live on campus and other select groups. Verily::: the company that has worked with us on many aspects of our testing program::: will notify you if you are selected for sentinel screening. The holiday weekend is fast-approaching. SGA President Demarcus Joiner has a reminder for our students that no matter where they choose to spend Labor Day weekend::: it's important to continue abiding by the health + safety protocols that keep us all safe.

- Mask up any time you're headed out
- Practice social distancing by keeping 6 feet between yourself and others
- Avoid large gatherings and indoor events where distance cannot be maintained

We hope you come back from this weekend rested and re-charged. We're looking forward to staying #TideTogether this semester!

"If all of us continue to do our part::: I believe we will get to a position to consider relaxing some aspects of the moratorium."

ICYMI: Dr. Pope::: VP for Student Life::: sent out a message to our student body this morning. Two weeks ago::: a 14-day moratorium on in-person student organized events was implemented. This moratorium is being extended through September 13.

During this Labor Day weekend::: we hope you will responsibly connect with your roommates or a small group of friends (3-4 people) and explore our campus and state. The Student Life team has put together a few things for you::: including a Labor Day Scavenger Hunt::: and several Tide Together Experiences which have social-distance friendly stops.

Student Life Labor Day Scavenger Hunt: http://bit.ly/UAScavengerHunt

Tide Together socially distant experiences: http://bit.ly/TideTogetherExperiences

See Dr. Pope's full message: http://bit.ly/DrPopeMessageSept4
#TideTogether

column1:
A message from President Bell regarding the upcoming holiday weekend ↓

Dear students::: faculty and staff:::

As Labor Day approaches::: we must all remain vigilant in following the Health and Safety protocols designed to help protect you::: your family and our University community.

Wherever you spend the holiday::: remember to:

- Wear your mask.
- Practice social distancing.
- Avoid large gatherings.
- Complete isolation or quarantine::: if applicable.

Our robust testing::: isolation and quarantine protocols make it possible for us to contain the coronavirus and keep us together this fall. To accomplish our goals::: it is imperative that all of us do our part::: in all settings on and off campus. Violations of our Health and Safety directives will continue to be investigated and appropriate actions will follow.

Our COVID hotline will remain open 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. throughout the weekend::: so please call 205-348-CV19 if you have questions or health concerns. Our Healthinfo website is continually updated with the latest information and is an excellent resource: healthinfo.ua.edu

Your continued commitment is the key to unlock the Alabama experience this fall and beyond. I hope you have a safe holiday weekend!

Tide Together:::

Stuart R. Bell
President

Accommodations are available for high-risk individuals. column1:
How often will buildings on campus be sanitized?
Will employees have to use their sick leave if they test positive or are exposed to someone who has?

Matthew Fajack::: VP for the Division of Finance and Operations::: answers these questions and more in COVID Conversations::: our FAQ video series with campus leaders. See the full playlist → http://bit.ly/COVIDConversationsYouTube #TideTogether

The latest from President Bell to our students::: faculty + staff:

As we accelerate education and enforcement efforts on and off campus::: we look to each of you to do your part.

Those who fail to abide by the Health and Safety protocols face serious consequences. To date::: we have issued more than 400 conduct referrals for COVID-related violations. Interim measures removing individuals from campus have been imposed in several of these cases. Those who blatantly disregard the rules will not be given the option of jeopardizing the semester for everyone else.

In addition to wearing your mask and practicing social distancing::: it is imperative that you comply with all aspects of our testing and isolation or quarantine protocols. Students with COVID symptoms should seek testing through the Student Health Center or the University Medical Center testing site at Coleman Coliseum: https://healthinfo.ua.edu/testing-information/

If you choose to test off campus::: you are required to share positive results with the CV19 Support Program immediately by calling 205-348-CV19. Anyone who fails to disclose a positive test or violates the University’s isolation or quarantine protocols is subject to severe disciplinary action: https://www.ua.edu/news/2020/08/what-to-know-about-isolation-quarantine-protocols/

To read the full message from Dr. Bell: https://president.ua.edu/news/a-message-from-the-president-5/

To our #UA community: Help us beat the spread of COVID-19 by downloading the GuideSafe Exposure Notification App. 👍 The app will anonymously notify you if you have been in potential close contact with someone who later reports a positive COVID-19 test result — without sharing your identity or theirs. It is a critical component to mitigating the spread of COVID-19. How it works → http://bit.ly/GuideSafeAppInfo

Please note: The Exposure Notification App doesn’t ask for any personal information::: including your name::: email address or phone number::: and won’t access any information on your mobile device. By using Bluetooth technology and not GPS::: the app doesn’t track your location. No location data is ever stored or exchanged::: and your personal information is never shared.

column1:
Today: Tuscaloosa Mayor Walt Maddox released an executive order to help ensure the health and safety of our UA + Tuscaloosa communities.

The order includes:
-Closing of bars effective for the next 14 days (Aug. 24-Sept. 8)::: starting at 5pm tonight.

-Elimination of bar service at restaurants::: for the next 14 days (Aug. 24-Sept. 8)::: starting at 5pm tonight. Only table service is allowed.

-Request of the Alabama Beverage Control Board that all of Tuscaloosa County be placed under a prohibition of sales of alcohol::: on-premises consumption at bars from Aug.24-Sept.8.

"The goal of all of these protocols is to keep our students on campus::: and allow our classes to be delivered in that way::: and by doing that we're able to flatten this curve and move forward in our semester. This is a very dynamic situation. We value our students' health::: their ability to get the most out of their Tuscaloosa and Alabama experience." - President Bell

Reality: 1% (3.3M)

Poll Question: How many people in your country have died from COVID-19?

Reality: 0.04% (131K)

Americans overstated the death number by 225 times.

People in France::: Sweden::: and the UK all overstated the same number by 100 times. People in Denmark were off by 300 times.

column1:
#TodayAtUA: President Bell joined Tuscaloosa Mayor Walt Maddox at Manderson Landing for a joint press conference.

"Our challenge is not the students::: our challenge is the virus.

What we have to do is identify where does the virus thrive and where does the virus spread::: and how can we work together with our students::: faculty and staff to make sure that we minimize those places and those incidents.

We have spent the better part of the last 5 months working days + nights::: preparing for our students to return. We have deployed every resource at our disposal to provide comprehensive testing::: contact tracing protocol::: education and training programs. We have redesigned and equipped our infrastructure to ensure that our classrooms::: dining facilities::: residence halls and other places on campus are as safe as they can be for students::: faculty and staff.

Thank you to our students::: parents and families who have entrusted us to provide a safe environment for them to continue to learn and to grow. By returning to the Capstone this fall::: they have demonstrated the incredible value that they place on the Alabama experience. I want them to know how much we appreciate them::: how hard we are working to keep the Alabama experience that they cherish intact.

The rise we've seen in recent days is unacceptable::: and if unchecked::: threatens our ability to complete the rest of the semester on campus. Now is the time for action." - President Bell

The most recent message from President Bell ↓

Dear students::: faculty and staff:::
This is a critical moment for The University of Alabama.

Despite the robust testing::: training::: health and safety measures we carefully and clearly implemented::: there is an unacceptable rise in positive COVID cases on our campus.

Make no mistake::: this trend is a real threat to our ability to complete the semester on campus. The solution is proven: testing::: mask wearing::: social distancing::: personal hygiene and compliance with crowd size limits are all that are asked as we work together to complete the semester together.

Violations to our health and safety protocols::: both on and off campus::: are subject to harsh disciplinary action::: up to and including suspension from UA.

UAPD and the Tuscaloosa Police Department are partnering to monitor bars::: restaurants and off-campus residences where the city’s COVID-19 ordinances and UA guidelines are not being followed. Joint task force officers are risking their personal health and safety to protect yours. UAPD officers are also focusing efforts on our residence halls and Greek housing to ensure safety and compliance.

Completing the fall semester together is our goal. The margin for error is shrinking.

Now is the time to take action::: commit to protect each other::: and hold each other accountable. Thank you for taking your responsibilities seriously. Together::: through shared sacrifice and commitment::: we will achieve our goal.

Tide Together:::
Stuart R. Bell
President

column26:
All::: I appreciate your likes. I was so bent out of shape yesterday::: I wrote the UA president. I encourage you to do the same. Squeaky wheel gets the grease::: right? Apparently::: we aren't being squeaky enough. Encourage your students to do the same. It can't hurt. My kid was very upset yesterday::: so I told his story out of concern. I believe at least one student will buckle under this system before COVID-19 takes any student lives. I've had too many friends who have lost children to suicide and I think this situation is the perfect storm to tip a kid toward giving up. Here's my letter titled Which Comes First: The COVID-19 Chicken or The Suicide Egg.

Dear President Bell:::

I you beg you to consider the thought that suicides will be the leading cause of any UA student deaths in the 20-21 academic year::: not COVID-19. I understand you are pressured by some folks who believe it is in the best interest of the student body to learn online to try to evade contracting COVID-19::: but please read my story. Today::: my normally confident and level-headed son who is a freshman engineering student called me and was quite upset. He didn't call because he was ill from a COVID-19 infection. He called because he was feeling sick to his stomach anxious over the fear of failing. To be completely clear::: this was compounded with a poor night's sleep after a break up with his girlfriend. I said to myself::: okay::: this is just one of those calls I'm going to get because he's a Type A freshman who hasn't faced much adversity in his life. I asked him why he was so bent out of shape over school::: knowing the break up was probably the majority of his issue. He said::: "Mom::: I wouldn't be afraid of failing my classes if i could go in person. I'm afraid I am not going to succeed with online learning. I'm unsure if I am getting all the course related emails. The book store ran out of chemistry lab books before could buy one and I have a lab this week. I didn't get my e-codes for some of my text books until literally hours before classes began. I am juggling when to be online and when I go in person." Despite being a very smart kid::: he's like every other freshman trying to figure out college and very worried knowing if he's on top of everything. He's also one of the many students who will go through a relationship break up. I know if he's feeling this way::: it's just as overwhelming for other students. As a matter fact::: I have read several similar struggles and worries shared on the parent Facebook page . It's one thing to end an academic year online::: but a much more frustrating situation to begin your freshman year online. I know it could be much worse. Past generations faced sending sons and daughters overseas to fight world wars. Thank God::: this is nothing like that. That's exactly why I ask you to fight for these kids to be able to attend in person. It's nothing as serious as a world war::: but it as serious as a suicide by one of the thousands of fragile::: inexperienced scared teens who are in your care. They really aren't that vulnerable to COVID-19::: but are extremely vulnerable crumble under the pressure to succeed. Please don't be the COVID-19 chicken incubating student suicide eggs.

Thank you for your time and consideration:::

Kim Orr

S - Sanitize your hands frequently
T - Track your symptoms daily
O - Observe social distancing
M - Mask up when indoors or near others
P - Plan to stay home when sick

More info: http://bit.ly/STOMPCOVID19 #TideTogether

These rules apply on campus or in town::: at local apartments or in a private house. Students found violating these health and safety rules and ordinances will be subject to disciplinary action.

While the University expects all faculty::: staff::: and students will be responsible and compliant members of the campus community as we navigate this academic year::: any individual who violates the health and safety requirements will be met with sanctions/discipline intended to strongly address the risks their behavior creates. Enforcement directives for individual students can be found here: https://bit.ly/UAReturnPlanEnforcement

Please note that these general guidelines for sanctions can be accelerated or modified as needed to address the specific situation. #TideTogether

column1:
An important message from Dr. Bell regarding safety + well-being of our campus community ↓

Dear students::: faculty and staff:::

The University recently shared with all of you the policies and directives that underpin our plan to return to operations this semester.

The expected rules and behaviors of all students and student organizations have been clearly defined. While we are appreciative to those who have taken these expectations seriously::: I am deeply disappointed that those guidelines are not being followed by each and every member of our student body.

This afternoon the Division of Student Life will announce additional directives that are focused solely on the safety and well-being of our campus community. That information also will be shared with the parents and families of our students.

Tide Together now more than ever::: we are seeing the harsh consequences at other universities which have been forced to close abruptly because safety protocols were not followed. The eyes of the nation are following us closely and I am confident we will meet and exceed our status as frontrunners.

Despite the challenges::: we can measure success by many benchmarks.

Our student re-entry testing is nearly complete and the positive rate is around 1%::: far below national averages. Results will be posted at www.uasystem.edu beginning Monday afternoon on the new System-wide data dashboard and will be updated as we move into sentinel testing.

More than 20 employees have been assigned to focus solely on exposure notifications::: isolation::: quarantining and sanitization protocols. More than 450 beds have been dedicated for isolation purposes. Although more than 90% of those beds are vacant::: we will expand those resources as needed.

Hundreds of hours have been invested by our Situational Response Team and the President’s Advisory Committee to develop and implement guidelines that are consistent with the UA System Task Force Comprehensive Health and Safety Plan. Their work continues 24/7.

As an institution::: we are 45:::000 strong::: representing every county in Alabama::: every state in the nation::: and most countries around the world. It is a privilege to lead you.

Please know that I am counting on each of you not only to do your part to keep our campus safe::: but to report any activities that you believe might compromise the overall health and safety of our University community. Reports can be made online or by calling 1-866-362-9476.

I look forward to your comments and suggestions::: which we urge you to share at president@ua.edu.

Thank you:::

Stuart R. Bell

President

column28:
As a 22+ year nurse::: I have appreciated some of the precautions with COVID-19 and have been complexed regarding other mandates due to this virus. But this post really made me think:::... I share it here for your consideration as well:

Thank you to whoever wrote this. I copied this and changed it a little.

******
What is the end game with the ‘rona? Anyone? 🦠

What is the magic formula that is going to allow us to sound the “all clear?” Is it zero cases? For a while::: the goal was to simply “flatten the curve:::” but now that we are disconnecting utilities for gatherings in California::: setting up check points in New York::: and recommending goggles (what’s next?)::: it seems as if there is::: in fact::: no end game. And::: truthfully::: the only way that we will see numbers drop is if we cease testing and stop reporting. Keep in mind that hundreds of thousands have shown up to be tested::: registered::: left due to long waits::: and still come up positive when they received their results. 🤷🏼‍♀️

Is it a vaccine💉? It took 25 years for a chicken pox vaccine to be developed. The smallpox inoculation was discovered in 1776 and the last known natural case was in 1977. We have a flu vaccine that is only 40 to 60% effective (that’s generous- the last two years it was more like 20-25%)::: less than half of the US population chooses to get one::: and roughly 20:::000 Americans still die annually due to flu or flu complications.

Oh::: you'll mandate it in order to attend school::: travel to some foreign countries::: etc.? We already have a growing number of vaccine researchers refusing proven::: tested::: well-known vaccines that have been administered for decades! Do you really believe the majority of people will flock to get a fast-tracked vaccine::: whose long-term side effects and overall efficacy rates are anyone's best guess? How long are we going to cancel? Postpone? Reconsider?

Now we are advised against in-person school until second quarter? What if October's numbers are the same as August's? Then what?

Move football to spring? What if next March is worse than this March?

When do we decide quality of life outweighs risk?

We understand this virus can be deadly for SOME::: but so are shellfish::: peanut butter::: and bee stings. We take risks every day without a second thought.

We know driving a car can be dangerous::: but we don't leave it parked in the garage for months on end. We know the dangers of smoking::: drinking::: and eating fried foods::: but we do it::: none-the-less. We speed on highways::: some idiots still don't buckle their seatbelts::: we take medications more than “as directed:::” and a good number of individuals don't think twice about unprotected sex.

Is hugging Grandma really more dangerous than rush hour on the freeway? Is going to a bar with friends more risky than four day old gas station sushi? Or operating a chainsaw?

When and how did we so quickly lose our free will?

I want a waiver that says::: "I understand the risks::: but I choose a life with hugs::: smiles::: college athletics::: the state fair::: concerts::: and school dances."

I understand that there is a minuscule possibility I could die but::: more probable::: I will end up feeling like junk for a few days.

I understand I could possibly pass this virus onto someone else::: but I can pass ANY virus onto someone else at any time until the end of time.

Are we busy living or busy dying?

It’s hard to tell these days.

. Ognisko zakażeń w kampusie uniwersyteckim
Studenci Uniwersytetu Alabamy rozpoczęli rok akademicki zaledwie 6 dni temu. Do tej pory na uczelni przeprowadzono łącznie 46 150 testów::: z czego pozytywnych okazało się 566. Najwięcej przypadków młodych ludzi zakażonych koronawirusem mieszka w głównym kampusie - odnotowano ich tam 531. Budynki w Birmingham i Huntsville łącznie notują 35 przypadków COVID-19.

Stuart Ray Bell rektor uczelni wezwał całą społeczność akademicką do współpracy w tym krytycznym momencie. Zaapelował o utrzymywanie wytycznych takich jak dystans społeczny::: noszenie maseczek i ograniczenia spotkań. Dodał::: że osoby::: które nie zastosują się do wytycznych::: zostaną zawieszone w prawach studenta.

column1: The first day of classes is just around the corner! There are a number of policies and procedures in place to ensure a safe environment for our students::: faculty and staff. 👍 A couple of our Capstone Men + Women are here to share information regarding limited capacity on Crimson Ride buses::: changes in dining::: requirements for face coverings in residential areas + more ↓ For more information regarding health + safety policies and enforcement::: click here: https://healthinfo.ua.edu/returnplan/directives/ #TideTogether

Important information for students who still need to meet the COVID-19 testing requirements ↓

Students who have not met testing requirements should NOT come to campus unless it's for testing. Reminder: classes start tomorrow. FREE testing is available at Coleman Coliseum daily from 7 am - 5 pm. No appointment required. Head to the link in our bio for all the details. Know a student who still needs to be tested? Pass this along to them! Details on testing → https://healthinfo.ua.edu/testing-information/student-testing/

More information on campus health + safety → healthinfo.ua.edu

"The University of Alabama has a proud tradition of excellence in many areas - and one of those is the way we take care of one another and our community. This semester::: I trust you will do your part to follow the guidelines to ensure we can stay healthy and remain on our campus. It's one important way that you can demonstrate your respect for those around you."

A lot of careful planning has gone into preparations for the safe return of our students::: faculty and staff. This semester brings shared expectations for our entire community::: such as wearing masks::: following social distancing guidelines::: and participating in the UA Healthcheck. More from President Bell ↓ See healthinfo.ua.edu for up-to-date information about our return to campus this week. 👍 #TideTogether

Masks are required on campus during the fall semester - and we're making sure our students have the PPE they need! 💯 DYK: This week::: we're distributing 60:::000 masks to students across campus. Grab one at the following locations from August 17-21 while supplies last:

Bidgood Hall (Student Services Suite 10)::: 8am-5pm

Gorgas Library (Capstone Drive Entrance)::: Aug. 17-18 - 8am-5pm / Aug. 19-21 - 8am-10pm

Student Recreation Center (Front Desk)::: 8am-5pm

Ferguson Student Center (Information Booth)::: 8am-9pm

More info on mask requirement: healthinfo.ua.edu 😷 #TideTogether

column1:
Updates have been made to The University of Alabama's plan for a return to full operations::: including the latest policies and directives related to health and safety.

To emphasize the importance of adhering to the University’s Health and Safety Guidelines::: stringent sanctions and discipline will be administered for violations. While the University expects all faculty::: staff::: and students will be responsible and compliant members of the campus community as we navigate this academic year::: any individual who violates the health and safety requirements will be met with sanctions/discipline intended to strongly address the risks their behavior creates. More information about how our health and safety guidelines will be enforced: https://healthinfo.ua.edu/returnplan/directives/enforcement/

With this policies and directives update::: students::: parents::: faculty and staff can find the latest information regarding testing::: visitor restrictions on campus::: possible changes in class format or schedule::: student and academic event limitations::: isolation and quarantine and COVID-19 training and Healthcheck. Find the full update here: https://healthinfo.ua.edu/returnplan/directives/

UA has also adjusted the 2020 Fall semester calendar. Fall Break will not be observed::: and in-person classes will end on the Friday before Thanksgiving. Classes will not be held Thanksgiving week::: but will resume the following week::: remotely. Final exams will be remote.

Please note that this information serves as an interim policy for Fall 2020 operations containing University directives. Compliance with its terms – and with further updates to be published at healthinfo.ua.edu – is required of all faculty::: staff::: students::: contractors::: and visitors on our campus. Failure to comply with any rules and directives will result in disciplinary action and/or removal from campus.

Progress will not stop with the issuance of this update. Throughout Fall 2020::: three teams will continue to function and will assist President Bell with ongoing response to COVID-19. These include the UA System Health and Safety Task Force::: the Situational Response Team and the Presidential Advisory Committee.

As the situation related to COVID-19 evolves::: the University’s protocols are subject to change. We encourage the University community to continually monitor official channels of communication including emails and the UA Health Info website: healthinfo.ua.edu
